EMXAWM.description:
CesiumJS is an amazing library for geospatial visualization, but is very bare-metal and you have to build your UI around it. An easier approach is using TerriaJS as your UI to interact with CesiumJS. This workshop will show you how easy that is to do!

## Details

TerriaJS builds upon CesiumJS’ 3D web geospatial visualization, adding a UI for exploring and previewing layers in a catalog, charts and graphs, a “splitter” interactive comparison tool, shareable story building and many other features. In this workshop, you will learn how to build and deploy a rich and compelling TerriaJS application, without writing any code. You will also learn how to extend TerriaJS with custom functionality as your application’s needs grow.

### Skill level

**Beginner/Introductory**

Some experience with JavaScript/NodeJS would be advantageous. Experienced people will not be bored as the sky is the limit.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Laptop with a working NodeJS installation and a text editor.
EMXAWM.title: Building your own CesiumJS map, made easy with TerriaJS

NNWXKL.description:
The workshop will include a brief overview of SOS (the OGC's Sensor Observation Service), and NIWA's Sensor Observation Services, to provide context, followed by the hands on workshop.

The workshop will take you through accessing a SOS service (using NIWA's as an example) using R on your own laptop to request specified data from the service, and how you can develop a simple R Shiny web application based on this.

## Details

SOS is becoming the global standard API for sensor (time series) data sharing. NIWA has deployed SOS services providing free public access to monthly climate data summaries, hydrometric and water quality data. The 52 North open source SOS Server application has been used for this. Custom NIWA middleware sits between our underlying databases and the 52 North software, so the system sits alongside our existing databases, simply adding a new mechanism for accessing the data.

NIWA has also developed client tools which users can use to access these services (yes, you can still use CURL if you choose). One is a custom QGIS plugin, which allows users to connect to a SOS service much as they can a WMS or WFS service. The sites of stations providing observations can be shown on the map, and available sensor data graphed and downloaded as required.

The second SOS client is a new SOS4R package, for the R statistical software program. This package provides two sets of capabilities: It can issue SOS requests and return data into local dataframes, but, and more usefully, it also supports a set of abstracted queries, built on top of the native SOS requests, which provides additional requests much more suited to how a user would want to interact with the service - a much more user friendly workflow. 

An R user can use this package to access a SOS service to request data to analyse locally, or as the data access tool for an R Shiny web application allowing others to interact with the service.

In R you will learn how to:

Get a list of sites (stations) which provide data (and which sites provide a specifies reading)
Get a list of what datasets (instrument readings) are available (and filtered by site)
Filter data requests by date/time
Request a dataset for a selected instrument from a site within a specified time period
Plot these data  

In Shiny, you will build a simple web site allowing users to view stations on a map, select a station, a reading , a time extent and download/plot the data.

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

You will need to be very comfortable writing R scripts for all parts of the workshop. Ideally, use R Studio as the IDE, as this works well with R & Shiny and allows you to easily publish your Shiny application on the web on their Shiny server. 

Familiarity with developing Shiny applications and using Leaflet for embedded maps will be useful for the Shiny part of the workshop.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Your own laptop with R & RStudio set up for use.
NNWXKL.title: Write your own SOS client for NIWA climate data with R Shiny

W8Y7UU.description:
Pattern matters! What is the most efficient way of allocating a limited amount of water or fertiliser across several paddocks? What is the best spatial land-use configuration to minimise environmental impact in a catchment? More generally, what is the best way of allocating a set of potentially limited resources to a set of locations or areas to get the best bang for your buck? If you are grappling with these types of questions, this workshop is for you! We will guide you step by step through the process of structuring, solving, and mapping spatial optimisation problems using the free and open source spatial modelling and optimisation framework [LUMASS](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home). Apart from basic GIS skills, we only expect your enthusiasm! Note: Linux or Windows laptop required!

## Details

#### Workshop Content
In this half-day workshop (WS), we provide a practical introduction to spatial optimisation (SO). At the beginning (30 mins.), we will provide a short overview of 

* the types of SO problems you can solve with [LUMASS](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home)

* what data you need to solve SO problems 

* and how to prepare and structure your data for solving SO problems with [LUMASS](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home).

In the remainder of the WS (3h), you will be working through the [LUMASS](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home) [OptimisationHowTo](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/downloads/OptimisationHowTo_1.2.zip) to replicate the SO scenarios as published in [Herzig et al. (2018)](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2018.05.005). You can either work completely by yourself and follow the document step by step and ask for assistance if required; or you can follow short demonstrations showing the next set of steps on the screen and then reproduce them on your laptop and then follow the demo of the next set of steps etc. There will be extra tasks for those who complete the [HowTo](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/downloads/OptimisationHowTo_1.2.zip) before the end of the WS. 
If you are a Linux user, please make sure to download the [source code](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/src/master/) and [compile](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/src/master/INSTALL) LUMASS on your machine prior to the workshop (don’t leave it to the last minute)! Please do [get in touch](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/lumass-users), if you’re hitting trouble! 

#### Material and Links
**Software & Data**

LUMASS: [https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/wiki/Home) 

OptimistionHowTo: [https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/downloads/OptimisationHowTo_1.2.zip](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass/downloads/OptimisationHowTo_1.2.zip) 

**Background Literature** 

Herzig A, Ausseil A-GE, Dymond JR 2013a. Spatial optimisation of ecosystem services. In: Dymond JR ed. Ecosystem services in New Zealand - conditions and trends. Manaaki Whenua Press, Lincoln, New Zealand. Pp. 511–523. [http://goo.gl/koaEhR](http://goo.gl/koaEhR) 

Herzig A, Nguyen TT, Ausseil A-GE, Maharjan GR, Dymond JR, Arnhold S, Koellner T, Rutledge D, Tenhunen J 2018. Assessing Resource-Use Efficiency of Land Use. Environmental Modelling and Software 107: 34–49. [http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2018.05.005](http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2018.05.005) 

There is more literature referenced in the OptimistionHowTo.

### Skill level

**Beginner/Introductory**

Basic GIS skills required.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

- bring a 64bit Windows laptop (windows binaries available for download)
- bring Linux laptop with LUMASS pre-installed, i.e. download and compilation by attendee required
W8Y7UU.title: Spatial Optimisation 101

SNN83F.description:
Do you want to create minimal nice looking maps without all the overhead of a typical mapping library? Are you bothered of all the extra stuff that obstructs the display of your geospatial data?
Using d3 is a great way to create minimal nice looking maps and this workshop will teach you the essentials you need to know.

## Details

The revised workshop is a hands-on, bring your device type of workshop where I teach participants with projects and exercises on how to create maps with d3.
The workshop showcases the essential features of d3 for quickly creating geospatial data visualizations, and the result is a choropleth map that every participant creates on their own and takes home.

Mapping in the browser is a hot topic, and there are plenty of tools and ways to visualize data. The power of d3 is the interactivity and closeness to the data.
Creating minimal looking maps with or without basemaps and still have interactivity is a great asset of d3.

The goal of the session is to provide the participants with the tools and the knowledge to create interactive choropleth maps from geo- and topojson files. Along the way, the base concepts of d3 will be covered as well.

Participants should know Javascript and should have worked with a mapping library such as OpenLayers, Mapbox GL, or Leaflet before.

Learnings: When is d3 the right tool for creating a map and the best approach to create a map with d3.

The topics include:

- Creating a simple map from both geojson and topojson
- Changing the projection of the map
- Creating a choropleth map
- Updating the map
- Adding interaction to the map
- Creating a tooltip
- Create a bubble map



**Learnings**: When is d3 the right tool for creating a map and the best approach to create a map with d3.

**What to take home**: Basic d3 Map with your data or an open dataset. 

**Required facilitations**: Local network, participants laptops, web browser

**Knowledge required**: medium-level Javascript knowledge, basic HTML, basic CSS

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

medium-level Javascript knowledge, basic HTML, basic CSS

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Laptop
SNN83F.title: Geospatial data visualization with d3

JX7NNK.description:
Digital Earth Australia have been working with FrontierSI to prepare a sandbox environment where you can use the Open Data Cube to explore over thirty years of Earth observation data covering the Australian continent. This workshop will introduce you to the Open Data Cube, the Jupyter data science environment, and analysis ready data in a live coding environment, the DEA Sandbox.

## Details

The Open Data Cube (ODC) is a collaborative effort to develop software and a community of users around a common goal of increasing the ease of access to Earth observation data. The increase in the number of Earth observing satellites over the past few years, coupled with new open data policies and new storage formats like Cloud Optimised GeoTIFF, means that there is a need for a standard way to plug in to this data and enable analysis processes. The ODC provides this way. 

This workshop will introduce you to Digital Earth Australia’s (DEA) implementation of the ODC, the DEA Sandbox, and through the use of the Sandbox, you’ll work through a suite of examples that show you what the ODC can do and what data DEA make available for Australia. This workshop will cover the following topics:
* What is analysis ready data
* What is Jupyter and how can I use it 
* Using simple Jupyter apps to explore data 
* Do-it-yourself example implementing NDVI from scratch
* Advanced example using Landsat 8 optical data to identify coastlines over time 
* Advanced example using Sentinel 1 radar data to identify water.

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

Some Python programming experience is required as this workshop involves some hands-on coding.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Attendees are required to bring a laptop with a modern web browser, preferably Google Chrome.

We require Internet access for the workshop participants.
JX7NNK.title: The Open Data Cube Masterclass

SQYRSK.description:
Everyone loves pretty maps! Regardless of your field, background, or software application of choice, we're all striving to make the most beautiful maps we can (as quickly as we can!). During this workshop I'll be showcasing a ton of cartographic tips and tricks to help make your maps prettier.

We’ll be leveraging QGIS’ rich cartographic features to explore how you can improve your maps through refined color choices, data-driven symbology, taming the labeling engine, and crafting automated print layouts. We'll also be exploring cartographic best-practice and how to follow this using FOSS4G software. No coding or development experience is required, and we'll be teaching techniques of value to both new and experienced users alike!

(Note that while we'll be using QGIS as the cartographic application of choice, many of the techniques demonstrated during this workshop can be transposed to other desktop GIS applications or web mapping platforms.)

## Details

Everyone loves pretty maps! Regardless of your field, background, or software application of choice, we're all striving to make the most beautiful maps we can (as quickly as we can!). During this workshop I'll be showcasing a ton of cartographic tips and tricks to help make your maps prettier.

We’ll be leveraging QGIS’ rich cartographic features to explore how you can improve your maps through refined color choices, data-driven symbology, taming the labeling engine, and crafting automated print layouts. We'll also be exploring cartographic best-practice and how to follow this using FOSS4G software. No coding or development experience is required, and we'll be teaching techniques of value to both new and experienced users alike!

(Note that while we'll be using QGIS as the cartographic application of choice, many of the techniques demonstrated during this workshop can be transposed to other desktop GIS applications or web mapping platforms.)

This workshop is being run by Nyall Dawson (from North Road Consulting), who is a frequent contributor to the QGIS desktop application and has been crafting maps for the last 10 years.

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

No prerequisite skills required! But don't misinterpret this as a "beginner" workshop -- even advanced users will gain new insights and skills...

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Please bring your own laptop with the latest QGIS release installed. Also bring any example maps you think are great, and would love to learn how to reconstruct!
SQYRSK.title: Creating beautiful maps quickly!

S7PXRA.description:
Mapbox GL JS is a free and open source JavaScript library for interactive, customisable vector maps on the web.

## Details

This workshop will teach you how to build your own interactive and customisable vector maps for the web.

Covering core concepts of modern vector maps and building with Mapbox GL JS including:
- Layers
- Sources
- Mapbox GL Style Spec
- Controls
- Markers
- Popups
- Expressions
- Feature States
- Custom Layers

Beyond the core concepts you'll learn some useful tips and tricks to deal with common scenarios.

Ideally participants would have at least basic JavaScript knowledge, but no prior mapping knowledge required.

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

Basic or higher JavaScript knowledge is strongly recommended. If you know what variables, functions, JSON and HTML are you should be fine.

No prior Mapbox GL JS experience required, but even if you've done a little bit with Mapbox before you'll hopefully still get value from the depth of topics which we'll cover.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

A laptop
S7PXRA.title: Mapbox GL JS

CZVKRS.description:
Do you want to make a beautiful map that you can publish on your own website? All without having to worry about all that techie hosting/databases/cloud stuff that can just be overwhelming?

Yes? Then this workshop is for you! You’ll find out what’s involved in creating your own self-hosted web map. (Without needing years of experience in software development to understand the process.)

## Details

You may have heard about new technologies like vector tiles, that let you make huge and complex data available as a web map, or those cloud services run by Amazon, or looked at the amazing services from Mapbox, but been nervous about what it would cost if your map suddenly got a lot of attention. Well, you don’t need any of those!

We’ll be using vector tiles to build a web map that you can upload to any web hosting service – from the cheapest shared web host to a WordPress site. No complex pay-per-month cloud services, no spatial web servers, and no databases - just a simple map that’s yours to own.

This workshop isn’t about learning to code, learning QGIS, or learning about data – it’s about putting those components together to achieve something bigger. We'll be walking you through the whole process of making the technology work for you step-by-step.

First, we'll take open data published by the New Zealand government and use it to create vector tiles. (Vector tiles are a neat new way to package up data in a way that’s ideally suited to web maps.) Then we’ll use Mapbox Studio to design a snazzy looking map with our data. Finally, we'll upload it to your very own website and share it with the world.

The maps we’ll be creating are ideal for those times you want to make a map that you can just upload and forget about. They're perfect for student projects, company websites, or for cartographers and designers who want to craft beautiful customised maps that are easy to hand over to clients.

The workshop will provide you with the knowledge you need to get started, but you're free to deviate from the examples that we provide as you grow more confident and start to explore the tools available to you.

Looking forward to seeing your creations!

Image: NZ Topo50 Map series from LINZ. Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license.

### Skill level

**Beginner/Introductory**

Audience: Beginner to intermediate-level.

Some basic programming knowledge may be advantageous, but not essential.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Please bring a laptop. Sorry, but tablets won't do :)

The software we'll be using will run on Windows, macOS, or Linux.

Further information on the software you'll need to have installed before the workshop will be circulated before the conference.
CZVKRS.title: Keeping it simple: Building a web map you can host virtually anywhere

RKAAHQ.description:
Static or interactive maps can reveal useful patterns and insights. For example, layering accident locations on a basemap can highlight hotspots of poor road safety. These simple data overlays can be extended to an integrated analysis with the road network for deeper insight - like accident hotspots on road segments that bottleneck commuter flows. As denizens of a city we primarily interact with the built urban environment via its streets, roads and paths. Hence, intuitive questions of the 'Urban Experience' must involve the geospatial road network.

## Details

In this workshop, we'll use Python and the packages, osmnx and pandana, to characterise Wellington: the cool little capital of New Zealand with a unique topography. Using omsnx, pandana and data of the built environment (from OpenStreetMap and Wellington City Council open data), we can quantify how Wellington functions as a city.

Foundational topics include:

- Handling geospatial data with geopandas
- Getting street networks with osmnx
- Routing with network algorithms
- Calculating flows from routes

Urban analysis topics include:

- Analysing street morphology and topography with osmnx
- Accessibility analysis with pandana
- Catchment areas of amenities with pandana

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

Participants will need to have some experience with Python programming to finish the exercises. An early intermediate level will be sufficient as the analysis will not involve heavy programming.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Attendees must bring their own laptops with Python 3, geopandas, osmnx and pandana installed. They will also need matlplotlib and basemap. A full list of packages will be provided closer to the workshop date. Attendees will also need a Google Elevation API key. Again, further details will be sent out later.
RKAAHQ.title: Analysing geospatial connectivity to understand a city

QSBVAQ.description:
The graphical modeller is a powerful component that we can use to define a workflow and run a chain of algorithms (a processing model).

A normal session with the processing framework tools includes more than running a single algorithm. Usually several of them are run to obtain a result, and the outputs of some of those algorithms are used as input for some of the other ones.

Using the graphical modeller, that workflow can be put into a processing model, which will run all the necessary algorithms in a single run, thus simplifying the whole process and automating it.

## Details

In this workshop we will create a processing model in the graphical modeller that displays buildings affected by some event within a distance from an event location.  

The affected buildings are determined by 
* Clicking a point on the map canvas to define an event location,
* travelling a distance along the road network from the event location, 
* buffering the travel distance to intersect land parcels, 
* extracting building footprints that that intersect the land parcels.

The Inputs
* Event location point chosen on the Map Canvas
* Road network layer
* Travel distance value
* Travel distance buffer value
* Land parcel layer
* Building footprints layer

The outputs
* Event location point layer
* Affected road network line layer
* Travel distance buffer polygon layer
* Affected buildings polygon layer

### Skill level

**Advanced**

Intermediate level QGIS minimum

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Laptop loaded with latest QGIS release.
QSBVAQ.title: QGIS Processing Models and the Graphical Modeller

SPGUQV.description:
This hands-on workshop covers the use of [PyGMT](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/pygmt) to analyze geospatial data and produce publication quality figures and animations in an interactive [Jupyter](https://jupyter.org/) lab environment. After a quick guide to launching up PyGMT on your computer, we will start with the basics of making your first map with PyGMT and explore some different customizations such as fancy projection systems and colormaps. Next we will teach you how to load in CSV point and GeoTIFF/NetCDF grid datasets using [pandas](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas) and [xarray](https://github.com/pydata/xarray), and have PyGMT perform more advanced geoprocessing workflows such as sampling, filtering and interpolation on them. Finally, we will step you through making 3D perspective plots and animations of your final results!

## Details

From processing raster grids and vector data (points, lines, polygons) to creating visually appealing maps in different projection systems, the [Generic Mapping Tools (GMT)](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/gmt/) is a swiss army knife collection of open source tools used by Earth, Ocean and Planetary scientists worldwide. [PyGMT](https://github.com/GenericMappingTools/pygmt) is a more user-friendly, Pythonic interface to GMT 6's modern execution mode that integrates well with the [PyData](https://pydata.org/) stack. This includes reading [numpy](https://github.com/numpy/numpy) arrays, [pandas](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas) tables and [xarray](https://github.com/pydata/xarray) grids, plus support for rich display in interactive [Jupyter](https://jupyter.org/) notebook environments. It is also a powerful library used for processing geospatial and geophysical datasets, including operations like sampling, filtering, interpolation and so on.

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

This workshop is intended for people with some previous Python programming/GMT experience. We invite students and geoscientists working on any geo related fields (e.g. Earth Observation, Geophysical, Marine, Magnetic, Gravity, Planetary, etc) to join. We also welcome seasoned GMT veterans who would like to find out how the Python interface works with GMT 6's modern execution mode and people from the geospatial industry with some Python programming experience that would like to get to know what PyGMT can do for parts of their geoprocessing workflow.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

A github repository containing jupyter notebooks for the workshop will be set up prior to the workshop. Users should only need to have a laptop with a modern browser that can launch an online [Pangeo Binder](https://binder.pangeo.io/) link/[Google Colaboratory](https://colab.research.google.com/) Jupyter computing environment. This should give everyone a relatively consistent experience.
SPGUQV.title: PyGMT for geoscientists - A PyData compatible package for analyzing and plotting time-series and gridded data

7AHC8Q.description:
What does it look like to work in the core C++ _(and Python, and Perl, and even a little bit of raw C)_ logic of QGIS?  
This workshop will cover an intro into building, understanding, and navigating the core QGIS codebase.   

This workshop will be an attempt to help demystify the QGIS core codebase in order to help ease you into QGIS core development.   There is no requirement to leave the workshop understanding every bit of the QGIS codebase as there is a lot and even some of the current core developers don't understand it all :)

## Details

What does it look like to work in the core C++ _(and Python, and Perl, and even a little bit of raw C)_ logic of QGIS?  
This workshop will cover an intro into building, understanding, and navigating the core QGIS codebase.   

This workshop will be an attempt to help demystify the QGIS core codebase in order to help ease you into QGIS core development.   There is no requirement to leave the workshop understanding every bit of the QGIS codebase as there is a lot and even some of the current core developers don't understand it all :) 

The main takeaways from this workshop is understanding the workflows core developers normally take in order to land a bug or feature into the next release.  Simply understanding where things are and how to navigate the code can lead to openings in fixing bugs or adding new features.  Starting simple and working your way up very much applies to QGIS.

Topics we will try to cover in the workshop are:

- Build setup
- Qt Creator
- Understanding where the code lives
- Navigate the code
- How the Python bindings are made (SIP - Here be dragons)
- Unit tests
- PR/Merge process (for features and bugs)
- 
Knowing C++ will help you in advance but it's not a requirement of this workshop so don't be put off by that.  There is more to the QGIS code base then a pile of C++ and this workshop will give you exposer to those other areas as well.

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

No skill level is required however as this will deep dive into some of the core C++ code logic attendees should be at least be comfortable with knowing that is going to happen and not being able to understand what is going on 100% of the time.

Past C++ experience will help but is not a requirement.

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Laptop
7AHC8Q.title: Demystifying QGIS core development

WB99J8.description:
A series of OGC Interoperability Experiments (IEs) have been working on techniques and technologies for the problem of linking multi-disciplinary and multi-organisation environmental data _without_ transferring data custody or maintenance responsibilities. These IEs, such as the [Second Environmental Linked Features Interoperability Experiment](https://www.opengeospatial.org/projects/initiatives/selfie) (SELFIE), are firmly grounded in W3C and OGC [best practices for spatial data on the web](https://www.w3.org/TR/sdw-bp/). They involve organisations from New Zealand and around the world, trying to find solutions to problems such as: sharing data for transnational groundwater monitoring; linking descriptions of things to related things (e.g. boreholes to aquifers); using [popular vocabularies](https://schema.org/) to semantically describe the properties of things while avoiding misinterpretation; describing links between distributed records for things that change in nature over time and space; for data publishers to associate related information maintained by third parties to their own data; and maybe even the [HTTPRange-14 problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTPRange-14). This workshop will first give an overview of **distributed and linked data** concepts: focusing on: why it matters for those responsible for publishing geospatial data; the advantages for those consuming geospatial data; and how search engines get involved. The SELF Interoperability Experiment will be discussed as an example. Then (and for most of the available time) we will work collaboratively to draft the publication of some spatial data using our laptops, taking advantage of these concepts in a way that will not alienate modern web developers or GIS practictioners, i.e. by using JSON-LD, semantic HTML, Web Components, and an implementation of the OGC WFS 3.0 specification for features.

## Details

## Learning outcomes

1. I understand what structured and linked data are.
2. I understand some benefits of structured/linked data.
3. I am aware of the OGC/W3C Best Practices for Spatial Data on the Web.
4. I know how to implement some of the Best Practices.
5. I understand, can re-state, and (perhaps) respond to some of the challenges, limitations, and criticisms of structured/linked data

### Note

Participants will be asked to optionally provide some sample data that may be suitable for publication using linked data concepts. Data from two domains that have a topological relationship are good candidates. If some interesting data are made available with sufficient time, the practical part of the workshop will be geared towards exploring that data. If not, some sample data will be used, at my (the presenter's) discretion.

I do expect you to do some "course reading" to gain a some conceptual understanding. Reading is food for the brain. Here are some foundational documents, in priority order.

- [Spatial Data on the Web Best Practices](https://www.w3.org/TR/sdw-bp/), W3C Working Group Note
- [Linked Data](https://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/LinkedData), Tim Berners-Lee
- [Background to the (first) Environmental Linked Features Interoperability Experiment (ELFIE)](https://www.opengeospatial.org/projects/initiatives/elfie)
- [Creating semantic sites with Web Components and JSON-LD](https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/03/creating-semantic-sites-with-web-components-and-jsonld)
- [Building JSON-LD APIs: Best Practices](https://json-ld.org/spec/latest/json-ld-api-best-practices/), W3C Draft Community Group Report
- [GraphDB: Introduction to the Semantic Web](http://graphdb.ontotext.com/documentation/standard/introduction-to-semantic-web.html) (Note: this is more advanced, and largely beyond the scope of the workshop. The intention is to get you thinking wide as well as narrow.)

However, don't stress! There will be no test. If, after doing some reading, you still don't understand the point of any of it, that's fine. There will be plenty of opportunities for discussion.

There *was* (and, to some extent, *still is*) a lot of misplaced hype about Linked Data out there in the untamed wildernesses of the Internet. Don't worry, I haven't drunk of the Semantic Kool Aid. This workshop will be reined in to practical applications rather than pure aspiration. You will come away thinking critically about these Linked Data ideas, perhaps seeded by some contrary opinions and writings by people who have/had their heads firmly screwed on:

- [Two Bit History: Semantic Web](https://twobithistory.org/2018/05/27/semantic-web.html)
- [Cory Doctorow: Metacrap](https://people.well.com/user/doctorow/metacrap.htm)
- [Aaron Swartz: A Programmable Web](https://archive.org/details/AaronSwartzAProgrammableWeb) (Note: this is a longer read than the others, but lighter and very interesting.)

### Skill level

**Intermediate**

Participants need to understand web development principles and various technologies and standards underpinning the web. If you've done some web development, or if some of these terms are vaguely registering, then we're good to go:

- Semantic HTML
- Linked data, RDF
- JSON (perhaps JSON-LD)
- HTTP REST
- OGC WFS 2 and/or 3
- Vocabularies/ontologies
- SEO
- Web Components

### Things to bring and stuff to do beforehand

Details will be sent out closer to the time, but the basics are:
- A well oiled brain (i.e. please do some reading)
- A laptop with a web browser (Chrome or Firefox preferred)
- Ideally a running instance of https://github.com/geopython/pygeoapi (I'm willing to help you set this up in the days and weeks leading up to the workshop if necessary)
WB99J8.title: An open data SELFIE: how we can improve open data for SEO, interoperability, and the web of data

MNVK8Z.description:
Wikidata is a project of the Wikimedia Foundation (the organisation behind Wikipedia), with the aim of developing a free and open knowledge base of structured data from Wikipedia, as well as WMF’s other projects and beyond.

Wikidata classifies around 60 million items (such as people, places, objects and works) into a highly extensible multilingual ontology, which can then linked to other Wikidata items or external datasets. Powerful query tools allow visualisation of the data as maps, timelines and a variety of charts and tables, or the data can be exported in a variety of structured formats.

This talk will be a quick introduction to Wikidata, and how you can construct your own custom open datasets on virtually any topic, and how the results can be used in a geospatial context.
MNVK8Z.title: The World of Wikidata

QS8ZRF.description:
In October 2019 we published *We Are Here: An Atlas of Aotearoa*. The book is a general atlas exploring New Zealand’s physical geography, climate, place, people, politics, economy and culture over 84 maps and data visualisations. With the exception of Adobe Illustrator and InDesign during the publication phase, the graphics were created with 100% open source software.

In this talk, we will share our general process from design to publication. Chris will discuss our heavy use of Python, QGIS, D3.js, Mapnik and the R Tidyverse. Tim will share the design goals and principles that guided our efforts. To illustrate these ideas we will go deep on a pair of graphics, stepping through how they were created.
There will be maps. Lots of maps.
QS8ZRF.title: Creating an Atlas of Aotearoa with open source software

BGN3NQ.description:
Ever imagined a future where the discovery and visualisation of 3D and 4D spatial data might be accessible to all on the web? The Terria team at Data61 have. Would you like a preview?

Today, Data61 is supporting Australian governments to accelerate collaboratively to a future state where authoritative 3D and 4D spatial data are readily available. Digital Twin prototypes are being developed with TerriaJS and Magda, integrating 3D and 4D datasets such as live transport data, infrastructure (above and below ground), building information models, cadastral data (property data), ‘photo reality mesh’ and more.

Our cities and communities have never been as data-rich as they are today. However, analysing and making sense of complex datasets can be difficult and time-consuming even for domain experts. Governments are looking to digital twins to enable the conversion of high volumes of data into valuable insights to inform decisions for designing, planning and managing our cities.

In this talk we will present on the advantages of using the open source and open standards based TerriaJS and Magda to create Digital Twin prototypes. We will share the challenges of 3D data, and what we have learnt to date. We will define what Digital Twins means to us, and others who we are collaborating with, and our vision for a national digital twin—an ecosystem enabled by collaboration and a federated approach. Oh, and of course we will do a demo!
BGN3NQ.title: Digital Twins with TerriaJS and Magda

TUJWNE.description:
QField is an optimized user interface for Android devices based on QGIS.

The requirements out in the field are not the same as on a desktop back in the office. The screen is smaller, the input devices are different and the tasks are generally very different.

QField aims to help the user to perform the field-based tasks they need to do without cluttering the user interface. This means, that only tasks which need to be done in the field are available from the interface. Everything else is not.

Tasks like layer styling, form definitions and other project setup steps should be done back in the office on a desktop computer with full QGIS installed first.
TUJWNE.title: QField: keeping it simple in the field

YFRDTQ.description:
This is a story of how we built an amazing open-source framework that **nobody could find**. Our users are delighted by it but are always amazed that more people do not know about it.  Buried deep inside was the rich data that our framework visualises, but is not accessible simply by searching for it with a search engine.

We'll go into the direction we chose for surfacing this rich metadata via "pre-rendering" our JavaScript, and why it was important in keeping compatible with our open-source philosophy. Dodging any particular vendor lock-ins, staying the platform-agnostic course, and the happy ending of how TerriaJS is able to bring its datasets to light.
YFRDTQ.title: Open Source Discoverability: beginning the journey of unearthing an abundance of hidden data

CDUVJ7.description: Maps! In the browser! Offline! **Yes it's possible,** yes in every (evergreen) browser, is it a good idea though? I'll show you how I did this with the open source framework TerriaJS, and how service workers can be applied more generally speaking to any web application.
CDUVJ7.title: Offline Maps in the browser!

D3TDLZ.description: As a largely visual medium with often complex controls, making map software accessible is very hard. Even developers and designers who are committed to accessibility are intimidated by the sheer magnitude of the challenges they are presented with. This talk explores some of these issues and shares some tips and tricks for making more accessible maps, with a particular focus on making map applications usable by keyboard alone. It is aimed at people who make decisions about the design of a map application, or anyone interested in accessibility.
D3TDLZ.title: A Journey Towards More Accessible Maps

CZXYN8.description:
In 2015 ANZLIC the Spatial Information Council for Australia and New Zealand decided to endorse the new metadata standard ISO19115-1 and retire the ANZLIC profile of ISO19115. It was felt that there was too much overhead involved in supporting a marginally different profile and that reliance on international guidance was a better path. This decision created problems on both sides of the Tasman due to slow international adoption of the new standard.  In New Zealand, where the tool sets most commonly used do not support the new standard, it was not adopted. In Australia, it was adopted but in different ways by different agencies which rather negates the value of a standard.

Now ICSM and ANZLIC have stepped up and are creating the needed guidance and support for ISO19115-1. Come see the tools and support being made available, learn how they may be of value and contribute your thoughts as to how they could better support our communities.
CZXYN8.title: Open Standards meets Open Source - Developing Good Practice Guidance for Use of ISO19115-1

JQLQ8P.description:
At Koordinates we've been using [Pytest](https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/) for all our testing. It's so much better than the other options that I cringe whenever I have to test a project that uses the stdlib.

We also make heavy use of [GDAL](https://www.gdal.org/), a broad and mature data-munging tool. Unfortunately, the test suite was 20 years old and homegrown. The test runner was quirky and hard to understand, and the tests were full of boilerplate.

At Pycon AU 2018 I happened across John Reese's excellent talk on [Refactoring Using the Standard Library](https://2018.pycon-au.org/talks/45063-refactoring-code-with-the-standard-library/) and realised I could use [Bowler](https://pybowler.io/) to do an automated rewrite of the GDAL test suite.

This talk describes my experience, including:
* the GDAL testing experience before and after my refactor
* the basics of automated refactoring
* how to avoid git conflicts when working on a large change like this
* how to actually get a [>100,000 line pull request](https://github.com/OSGeo/gdal/pull/963) merged upstream (!)
JQLQ8P.title: How I auto-refactored GDAL's test suite

MLERVW.description:
Explore the learnings and successes FrontierSI has with embracing the agile principles to deliver complex Geospatial projects.
We will explore the challenges we where facing in project delivery, how we implemented agile principles and processes to reduce our risk and achieve improved sustainable delivery.
Finally how organisations can explore agile delivery with targeted experiments.
MLERVW.title: Agile Delivery in the Geospatial Industry at FrontierSI

BQNQZK.description:
More than 4000 Earth observation satellites are presently in orbit, collecting Petabytes of data relating to changes on the Earth’s surface. While many of these commercial data sets are heavily monetised, the European Space Agency’s Copernicus programme has released a variety of products under open source licensing. The ability for users to harness such powerful data has been a key driver in the democratisation of satellite data and has allowed grassroots organisations to analyse and disseminate observed changes at the planetary and local scale.

One such product is Orbica Explorer: a web service where temporal change of land use is the focus. Using Sentinel-2 multispectral imagery, a region of interest over different time periods can be simply visualised. Additionally, a range of derived products can also be visualised in the same manner such as vegetation and water indices.  Based on FOSS Leaftlet and Postgresql stacks, it is envisaged that Orbica Explorer will put the most up-to-date imagery in the hands of interested users, in an easy-to-use way that will facilitate the answering of questions relating to our changing planet.
BQNQZK.title: Orbica Explorer – A temporally rich web-tool for viewing Sentinel-2 satellite data

SCVQ9C.description:
The New Zealand Transport Agency (NZTA) is working towards providing more accessible, frequent and affordable transport choices, particularly in high-growth areas.  This was part of a wider scheme of developing some national transport access measures with a focus on improving access to the transport system. MRCagney worked collaboratively with NZTA to develop and implement a methodology to measure access to public transport in the major cities of Auckland, Wellington and Christchurch.

The measure we computed for NZTA was based on walking catchments to stops and stations that meet a certain threshold relating to ‘frequent’ services across the full public transport networks in Auckland, Wellington and Christchurch. This is a way of quantifying access to public transport that goes beyond simple proximity to bus stops. To do this task, we used entirely open source tools, including Python, Open Street Map, General Transit Feed Specification and GeoPandas. In my talk, I will explain our approach, tools and results. In particular, I want to share our experiences of:

- General Transit Feed Specification data
- Pros and cons of using an API to compute walking catchments
- Communicating with our client as we came across challenges with the approach

By working closely with our client at NZTA, we were able to develop a methodology using FOSS4G to measure access to public transport across the full Auckland, Wellington and Christchurch regions. The key metric we provided to NZTA was, for each city, the proportion of the population within walking distance of frequent public transport. Using Folium, we created interactive maps to enable NZTA to review the catchments for each region, to identify which areas have walking access to frequent public transport. For stops or stations that did not meet the frequency threshold, we created maps that NZTA could use to understand why they were excluded.

The outputs were well received by NZTA and have been included in their reporting of national transport access measures. We are excited to explore the potential to further develop this measure to better understand issues around equity of access to public transport for different user groups.
SCVQ9C.title: Access to Public Transport

J8SVAB.description:
## Using GIS tools to assess the Apia Water Catchments Post Tropical Cyclone Gita.

The period of torrential rainfall before and during Cyclone Gita hit Samoa in early February 2018 resulted in the most extensive and intense flooding ever experienced in the Apia Urban Area. The assumption by environmental specialists is that developments up on the upper and middle water catchments in Apia (which includes clearing of land, vegetation, farming, buildings and roads) is contributing to the continual and now more frequent, intense and damaging flash floods. On 27th February 2018, the UNDP Multi-Country Office in Samoa contracted SkyEye to undertake mapping and assessment of the impacts of Cyclone Gita and changes in terrain, vegetation, developed areas in four of the urban water catchment areas since 2015.  The results of the assessment will help inform the Post Disaster Rapid Assessment led by the Samoa Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MNRE). Specifically, SkyEye was to deliver three key products: Provide High-Resolution Spatial Imagery and Maps of the four Watershed Catchment areas, Provide a Report detailing the spatial imagery and an assessment of damage to assess aspects of the environment and Provide GIS training for relevant staff of MNRE. Between March and April 2018, SkyEye captured, mapped, digitised and assessed the state of changes in the environment totalling 57.91 km² across four Water Catchment Areas in North Upolu. The geospatial images captured were assessed against imagery from 2015 provided by MNRE.

## Ala Addressing System - Solving the problem of no street addresses in Samoa

How QGIS contributed to solving the problem of a lack of street addresses in Samoa. Finding places/addresses is really difficult because Samoa, like other Pacific Islands, does not have an official addressing system. So we came up with a solution to address this problem. The project involved creating 823 2 km² Grids covering all of Samoa's Landmass. We created 2 m² grids within each 2 km² grid. The 2 m² grids were used to create centroids with a geometry attribute (x, y coordinate). This coordinate represented what's called an "Ala Number" which can be identified as an individual's/family's address (e.g. Ala Number 23-2-345 (Grid 23 - Column 2 - Row 345). The purpose of this project is to provide a logical and localised addressing system for Samoa and hopefully the Pacific; to allow for easy addressing for Pacific Islanders on the global market; and help improve government services and project implementation. There was a need to develop this system now, or else Samoa would miss out on possible future developments. The system is currently being integrated into an app we recently launched called Maua (Samoa’s first e-commerce platform). The idea is to hopefully have this system become Samoa’s official addressing system. It is currently in the talks as SkyEye is one of the committee members for Developing Samoa’s official addressing system.
J8SVAB.title: SkyEye Community Projects: Post-Tropical Cyclone Gita & Ala Addressing System

PMPDKJ.description:
Point-in-polygon lookups are a pretty common requirement in many applications: what local government area is this address within? What remoteness classification? What state?

To do this on the fly in a web mapping application typically requires either hosting a server with GIS and an API (and all the associated infrastructure) or paying for a service such as Mapbox’s Tilequery service.

I’ll show a cunning way to use any hosted vector tile source for point-in-polygon lookups, including those hosted on serverless systems such as Amazon S3. You can even use this on existing tilesets, such as those hosted by Australia’s NationalMap. It uses several open source JavaScript libraries, including Turf, to fetch a specific tile, convert it to GeoJSON and find the matching polygon.

This a technical talk for which some basic JavaScript understanding is useful. But the overall method may get you thinking about ways to overcome the assumed limitations of vector tiles.
PMPDKJ.title: Point-in-polygon lookups with vector tiles: quick, effective, and no server needed!

GSHTWX.description: A major goal for Digital Earth Australia is to help businesses use free satellite data to gain actionable insights. But to understand how best to help them, we needed to understand what information they lacked and why they weren’t already using the data. In this talk, I’ll cover how a data scientist and a DevOps engineer teamed up to engage with our users, and how we leveraged what we learned to build something truly useful.
GSHTWX.title: Lessons from a first brush with user experience design

UZPNDF.description: It's the absolute truth of workplaces today that we crave efficiency. QGIS has an amazing talent for delivering beautiful maps in a uniform way that makes us look good as well as saving time, money and thinking space. In this presentation, I'll cover client input, workflows, using variables, symbology tools, project structure, template design, current useful plugins and the possibilities a personal plugin will deliver.
UZPNDF.title: Workflows to repeat: QGIS Efficiencies

CKPSYW.description: We (a group of OSM and opensource enthusiasts in French Polynesia) will share with you where we stand, who we are, after almost one year of activity and what our biggest challenges are. We will present you a challenging project we have about mapping accessibility for disabled people, made with disabled people. We want to support urban planning, foster active mobility and support a strategy for an adapted tourism. Our main challenge: how to make people and local communities seize the potential of OSM and take part in this ecosystem (at present our group is made up mainly of metropolitans). Our metric for success: OSM contributions are easy to understand for anyone, including the disadvantaged, and the local national geographic institute shares their data into OSM and are willing to work with this ecosystem.
CKPSYW.title: Feedback on a new OSM movement in French Polynesia

MMXJQR.description:
Routine scientific analysis tasks should be perfectly reproducible, like a pure function: the same output for the same input, and without modifying the input data. This must apply across different computers. If this is not achieved, the result is potentially unverifiable. In addition, it should be possible to rapidly iterate ideas and formulæ as part of a semi-interactive process of experimentation (and debugging). Finally, we should ensure the whole thing is easily put under collaborative version control.

For some time I have been working with a workflow that I have found very useful to achieve these outcomes. It is primarily a combination of [Docker](https://www.docker.com/) (for containerisation and management of dependencies) and [GNU Make](https://www.gnu.org/software/make/) (for launching multi-step workflows with a complex dependency graph). In this lightning talk, I will outline this workflow. Hopefully you will be left with ideas about how you can make your computational process for geo-scientific exploration more resilient, whether or not you use Docker or Make.
MMXJQR.title: How I use Docker and Make for reproducible workflows

WDCPTE.description: The development of free and open-source routing software has led to an increased usage of path-finding and route analysis in novel and niche applications. pgRouting is an extension of PostgreSQL and PostGIS that provides several algorithms that are dedicated to solving geospatial routing problems, including All Pairs Short Path, Bi-directional Dijkstra, A*, and several others. pgRouting finds paths based on dynamic costs and is thus generalisable to any path or network topology. Although pgRouting has seen many niche applications, such as emergency routes in the face of natural disasters or routing for specialized shipping vehicles with complex turn and road restrictions, a vast majority are based on human transit and routing within cities. Applications of pgRouting to model movements of animal species are essentially non-existent. Yet, these can provide an interesting case study of the power of pgRouting to model movement and in route discovery. Such use-cases are particularly informative about the migration behaviour of species and have a very large application in the field of ecology and behavioural biology. A significant challenge of this application is that most natural environments lack “roads” or other features that can be utilised as a network topology along which routes are found. This presentation introduces developments that are being made to generalise route network creation in natural environments and demonstrates the application of pgRouting in describing the movements of fishes in the Samoan mangrove-seagrass-reef seascape.
WDCPTE.title: Fishing for routes: exploring the application of pgRouting to model the navigation and movements of fishes in highly heterogeneous marine environments

VZNFG9.description:
For 50 years we have been storing spatial data in digital formats that are based on old analogue systems for navigation and positioning that have never quite fit neatly in modern information systems. How big is a point provided as a Lat/Long value? Discreet Global Grid Systems (DGGS) provides a digital-friendly area based alternative that acknowledges that the earth is round.

DGGS does this through nested equal-area regular geometries, each identified by a consistent intelligible indexing system. Lightweight and fast, DGGS provides an inherently scalable system that addresses both vector and raster data. 

DGGS is a joint ISO TC211 and OGC standard project.
VZNFG9.title: DGGS - The New Digitally Friendly Format for Spatial Data

RDTJTB.description: NIWA has worked with Catalyst IT to develop a website providing plots and maps displaying a range of data pertaining to species captured during over 25 years of surveys on the Chatham Rise, off the South Island's east coast. Using Leaflet, D3.js and Plotly, this website breaks from the traditional web portals with a complex  hierarchy of pages to navigate and presents all the data on pretty much a single page, providing both species-centric and data-centric views, species details, presence/absence maps, interactive plots and maps comparing species data and distributions, as well as species changes over time. This presentation describes this innovative approach and invites people to play on the web site.
RDTJTB.title: A new paradigm in web visualiation of species data

KPVMYP.description:
GNS Science frequently needs to publish datasets composed with 50-100 layers on the web in conjunction with public datasets from diverse sources. Using a template and configuration files is the well-worn path and GNS Science has extended this to a configuration database where permissions, behaviours and presentation can be easily maintained with a web application known internally as jsMapservice. Built to handle data sources from OGS, ArcGIS, KML, Google and TMS, it feeds a template created from LeafletJS and AngularJS.

Internally, datasets created initially in GIS, are uploaded to Geoserver and PostGIS, while ArcGIS mxd files are converted into JSON for importing into jsMapservice map configurations. A Python script polishes metadata and imports into GeoNetwork.

Dataviewers can also be created in the jsMapservice application which connect spatial datasets to related data sources and allow for queries to be combined across local JDBC data sources and remote WFS or ArcGIS data sources.

jsMapservice with its associated tools has allowed GNS Science to effectively exploit the open source platforms used for rapid publishing of data under scientists control.
KPVMYP.title: jsMapservice - leveraging the open source stack for rapid publishing of spatial data

VUSMP7.description:
### Overview

Providing the Antarctic policy community, the tools and knowledge to support environmental management is critical for both the health of the Antarctic environment but also the Antarctic Treaty itself. Using OSS, Manaaki Whenua has developed the Antarctic Data Analysis (ADA) tool to provide context to, and assist, the Antarctic Policy community in the planning, permitting, and implementation of Antarctic activities. ADA eliminates the need for desktop geographic information system software or advanced technical expertise, by processing and presenting data in an easy to use way. This results in a site that allows users to discover, query and visualise spatial and temporal data relating to how Antarctica is changing. 

### Users

The tool was primarily built for environmental managers, and parties to the Antarctic Treaty and the Committee for Environmental Protection. The tool has been developed with input from the Antarctic Policy community and we expect that the tool will be utilised to support the conservation and management of the Antarctic continent. The site provides the users with maps and data illustrating various aspects of the continent, including facilities, environmental management, biogeography, human activity, climate, and geology.  

### Interaction and design

The map (OpenLayers 4/Mapserver/Mapcache) is supplemented by controls that enable querying at a single location, comparison between two locations, or along a transect line. These queries are based on a server-side API service, using NodeJS, that allows the user to query of all the terrestrial data within the tool. Non-spatial data is visualised using D3JS, which provide a range of charts and graphs that are built dynamically.
The technical approach used to visualise spatial data within the tool varies with the type of data being visualised. For example, a series of hexbin maps display human activity data. They are created dynamically (per zoom scale and per year) in the application using OpenLayers as the user interacts with the map with a time slider. 
To support the primary users (Antarctic environmental managers) to discover information about a location and how it is changing over time, a "Query Builder" was built which poses a series of queries which the user may be interested in. These queries create a “path” through the website as a series of steps, supporting the users to enable them to discover the answer to their question but at the same time helping them to learn how to use the application.

### Future

The ADA tool was presented at the recent Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting and will continue to be developed to support new knowledge on how the continent will change. The site builds upon a range of existing web sites such as the Antarctic Environments Portal, Our Environment, S-map Online, and the New Zealand Soils Portal. These sites were designed, created and are maintained by the Informatics Team at Manaaki Whenua.
VUSMP7.title: Antarctic Data Analysis: Supporting the environmental management of Antarctica using geospatial data and OSS

HPYEYS.description: ...or, if you want the formal title: "The difficulties with cross-cultural open-source development communities: case studies and examples from the QGIS.org project". During this talk I'll be ripping back the curtain and telling some funny (and informative) stories from my experiences within the QGIS community. You'll laugh, you'll cry, and with a bit of luck... you'll learn some useful techniques for managing inter-cultural communities!
HPYEYS.title: M̶e̶r̶r̶y̶ ̶C̶h̶r̶i̶s̶t̶m̶a̶s̶ QGIS!

EFW3CZ.description:
Open source software is fantastic! It's as good (or better) than the commercial counterparts, it's free to download and flexible for use. So why is it so hard to get adoption? Why isn't commercial software a historic artefact, and open source used everywhere? Why is the path to open source adoption so difficult to navigate and often full of heartbreak?

During this talk we'll explore the reasons why open source traction is difficult to start and maintain, we’ll give examples from our years of experience, and provide suggestions and counter-arguments for the commonly encountered issues.
EFW3CZ.title: Why is it so hard?

TV88WL.description:
In 2019 there are a host of JavaScript libraries which make it possible to work with GeoTIFFs directly in the browser. In this talk we’ll look at how people can go about loading, visualising and even analysing GeoTIFFs with 0 server-side technology. 

We’ll talk about some of the benefits of this approach, as well as some of the challenges and limitations that are encountered.

With GeoTIFF being the *de facto* raster format and a web-browser being an ever-available platform the opportunity to combine these technologies in a light-weight way to explore raster data is bound to open up opportunities.
TV88WL.title: Wrangling GeoTIFFs in the browser

AXRSVG.description:
Under the Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction, the Fijian National Disaster Management Office (NDMO) identified a significant role that SBT and ICT can play to reduce vulnerability and improve resilience. By integrating SBT and ICT tools, with national disaster risk management architecture, timely and accurate information can be delivered to relevant communities, individuals, rescuers and decision makers to save lives and properties at risk. The project was funded by the Japanese Fund for Poverty Reduction, with technical assistance from the Japanese Aerospace Exploration Agency, Asia Institute of Technology Geomatics Centre, Asian Disaster Reduction Centre, Remote Sensing Technology Centre and Geothings. 

Work carried out was divided into 5 sections:
1. Local communities digitised building and infrastructure in Open Street Map
2. Local communities with assistance from mobile app developers designed a base map to fit the purpose of the project. These include building attributes, conditions, height and materials. 
3. Recording capacities: using a geobinning app, disaster capacities and vulnerability are identified and mapped out in real time. Community hazard maps were generated out of this work. 
4. Recording: during a disaster, users can record information including disaster situation, building damage, and needs assessments. This information is sent to the operation centre for assistance, all in real time. 
5. Emergency Observation: using satellite data, and the community base map, it was possible to estimate damage extents.

Local communities were trained to use the tools to record flood- and cyclone-related vulnerabilities and capacities in villages. All these tools and reports are updated on the website monitored by the NDMO Operations Centre. Two critical maps came out of this work: 1. Community-based hazard map, and; 2. Evacuation map. These are the base map used for the village to seek shelter and identify hazard areas and planning.
AXRSVG.title: Applying Space-Based Technology and Information and Communication Technology to Strengthen Disaster Resilience in Nadi, Fiji

Q3N8CT.description:
The noted Australian Indigenous Elder and author of "Dark Emu", Bruce Pascoe said of Australia... 
"Indigenous place names hold rich information about our land, histories and cultures. Conversations about these places will increase local understanding of this country we share"

So the question is "how as Cartographers and data gatherers, can we promote this ideal whilst respecting the traditions and Elders of these languages and how do we empower the traditional owners to provide their knowledge of their world"?

### The Yarn... ###
I will 
* take you through some early Australian mapping and perhaps TImor Leste or pacific island depending on resources. 
* explain the issues of having 200-300 mainly extinct Australian languages 
* how the OSM ID can be altered to improve usability.
* provide a statistical summary
* hint of a new product being created (permission to be sought if successful)
Q3N8CT.title: Mapping in the International Year of Indigenous Languages

FVLQSL.description: In this connected world, Papua New Guinea is advancing in gradually in every facet of welfare and well-being. It seems like that the full potential of technological realization and its usefulness to offer readable solutions to our modern world is blinking. There is a great giant of psychiatric development whereby students and literate people step backwards in time and isolate themselves in this connected world. Isolation has become second nature to many literate people due to what is called "geographical determinism". The geographical nature of this beautiful country makes its difficult to foster, fortify and empower literate people to think like there is no box. Anything is possible when the mind is willing to do whatever it thought to do. This lightning talk will also highlight the possibility of connecting people through infrastructure such as road network using spatial data platform and open QGIS software. Once we get connected with one mind, then the giant of isolation will vanish away from our sight and PNG can rise beyond the horizon of isolation.
FVLQSL.title: A great giant of isolation in Papua New Guinea!

NSQUFQ.description: Geometry Generators are one of QGIS's many under-appreciated super powers. In this talk I'll show you what they are and how you can use them to do neat things.
NSQUFQ.title: QGIS Geometry Generators

GKNJXD.description:
A good map both functions well and is designed well. Sometimes it's easy to leave the design phase out, especially when time is precious or when the focus is on functionality. So how do you work with a designer to produce the best outcome? Or even do the design yourself? A GIS specialist who can do amazing things with geospatial data and create rich interfaces doesn't necessarily have all the user-centred or visual design skills to create a complete experience.

This talk will go through a framework for designing really amazing maps and go through case studies of how the framework can be applied to mapping projects. Examples shown will cover tools such as QGIS and OpenStreetMaps via Mapbox. I hope to leave you with a better sense of the endless possibilities of how maps are designed and how they complement the deep functionality you can create. Together, your strong technical skills can and newly honed design skills can shape people's wonderful map experiences.

This is a companion talk for technicians/developers that reflects an original presented for designers in [April 2019 in Melbourne](https://smallmultiples.com.au/articles/what-to-think-about-when-designing-maps/).
GKNJXD.title: How to put on your designer's hat when crafting map experiences

9JNWKC.description: A vast majority of Pacific Island communities are unplanned informal settlements because of a number of reasons ranging from land tenure to cost of land. These communities are also the most vulnerable to climate change impacts and to be helped, they need to be mapped. This presentation will be centered on the challenges of mapping informal settlements with relation to both open source software's and access to other resources.  Public opinions on possible solutions will be highly appreciated.
9JNWKC.title: Challenges of Mapping Informal Settlements

7V8QGE.description: Geospatial shares the opportunities and the challenges of both high performance computing and big data. With applications from visualising IoT data through to ingesting drone footage, it brings with it increasingly large data sizes, complicated data pipelines, HPC-level transformation demands, and often massive traffic from public users. From Smart Cities through to location-based marketing, rapid analysis of large volumes of geospatial data is becoming increasingly important. In this session, you will hear how AWS customers build powerful, flexible, secure, and future-proof geospatial platforms. These systems deliver more business value from location-based data while minimising both compute costs and management overhead.
7V8QGE.title: Running Geospatial Workloads on AWS

AEZRZB.description: Here we presented a framework for beach litter monitoring process, based on free and open-source softwares, allowing the adjustment for any scenario, using QGIS for sampling design, QField for fieldwork and R to perform the statistical analysis. The aim of the framework is to improve the current gap between fieldwork and analysis, producing baseline information on litter issues, such as amounts, sources, spatial and temporal patterns. Its usefulness was tested in a case study along three sites located in the Praia do Cassino, southern Brazil. Results obtained from the open-source geospatial framework application provide optimal information on spatial and temporal beach litter patterns. From the end of the fieldwork to the final products, less than an hour is expected. The reproducible R code provided by this framework results in a series of graphical and basic statistical products which can give support for future litter management actions.
AEZRZB.title: AN OPEN-SOURCE GEOSPATIAL FRAMEWORK FOR BEACH LITTER MONITORING

KYAEDZ.description: Coordinates and the reference systems within which they are defined underpin all of GIS. It is the use of coordinates and the consequent implicit spatial relationships between features which define GIS. However coordinate reference systems can be hard to understand. Confusion is exacerbated in modern times when users have as ready access to global coordinate reference systems such as WGS84, as they do to local systems such as NZGD2000 (New Zealand Geodetic Datum 2000). These have quite different characteristics and spatial errors of up to a metre can be incurred if they are confused. Furthermore, the relationship between them is not constant – it is a function of time. New Zealand straddles the boundary of the Pacific and Australian plates and is continuously deforming, so the time dependency of coordinates and coordinate transformations is particularly complex. This presentation uses the development and maintenance of NZGD2000 as a case study to examine the need for and challenges of time-dependent coordinate transformations.
KYAEDZ.title: Why are coordinate transformations so confusing?

TLUS7M.description:
I first encountered OpenStreetMap in 2013. That was the year when a powerful cyclone, Super Typhoon Haiyan, hit the Philippines. After that, I have continued to participate in the OSM and OSGeo community while working in places hit by disaster or war, whether in reconstruction, disaster preparedness, or urban design. I have also used OSM and QGIS for my hobby of making maps of islands.

In this lightning talk, I would like to share a short story on why volunteering with the open mapping community matters to me as a resident of the Pacific. I would also like to share how I have tried to grow with the community, as well as how I intend to continue meaningful relationships in the Pacific side of OSM and OSGeo.
TLUS7M.title: How to Map an Island in the Pacific

JBZJFX.description: A short overview of different ways to contribute to OpenStreetMap
JBZJFX.title: Practical Mapping Tips

EMEZEP.description: This project focuses on two cases, located in Waimakariri and Rotorua districts, in which new spatial tools are being co-created with rūnanga to improve collaborative town planning processes for Māori and address specific community planning needs. In order to collaboratively define how map-based tools can address specific community perspectives, the Geospatial Research Institute (University of Canterbury) engaged key community representatives of the two case studies, establishing partnership frameworks for the implementation of the research project. The map-based tools intend to support better integration of mātauranga Māori in town planning and aim at enabling whanau to document and share their traditional narratives and lived experiences to engage the communities in the creation of a shared vision for the regeneration of their villages. The pilot is being co-designed to promote the development of cultural mapping by the whanau, the primary end-users of the tools, connecting the stories and cultural layers to whenua. During the development of the map-based tools, it is imperative to maintain an iterative and active communication with the community partners to continue integrating their views at all levels, to ensure that the user experience reflects their tikanga and ways of knowing. The two map-based tools are being developed in Django, orchestrating the open-source database system extended with spatial capabilities PostgreSQL/PostGIS, the spatial data server GeoServer, the mapping API OpenLayers for interactive maps, and the JavaScript framework Vue.js for reactive user interfaces. Given the public nature of the project, the rationale for using open source technology is primarily to minimise the costs of implementation of the map-based tools, envisioning the free ongoing use of the applications by rūnanga and other small to medium-sized communities. The map-based tools are being developed with Māori for Māori communities, fostering ownership, belonging and self-determination.
EMEZEP.title: Map-based tools for Māori communities

U3LEYU.description:
As one of the world’s most ecologically diverse countries, Australia has experienced rapid changes as a result of human pressures and is particularly vulnerable to climate change.  With a land area of over 7,000,000 km<sup>2</sup>, understanding the state and condition of this ever-changing environment and identifying options for future management remains a significant challenge. 

How can we monitor the health of our environment and how it’s changing over time? What action can or should we take? How do we tell if measures to improve our environment are working as expected? These are some of the problems we are addressing with our new land cover classification and change detection system. Based on open Earth Observation (EO) satellite imagery, and building on existing open source software, this system will enable us to understand how our environment has changed over the past 30 years and guide in our decision making going into the future. 

Digital Earth Australia (DEA), powered by the Open Data Cube (ODC), offers a framework for continuous land monitoring using earth observation data to produce a range of open access land products targeted to decision-makers, practitioners and scientists. At Geoscience Australia we are collaborating with partners to build on this innovative framework and create an open source library which generates consistent land cover classification and change maps based on the Food and Agriculture Organisation’s (FAO) Land Cover Classification System (LCCS). The system builds on, contributes to and feeds back to other projects and research undertaken in Europe. Its development within the ODC environment will facilitate its use in countries or regions that are adopting this technology.

This presentation will cover how we’re bringing all this together, and what makes our approach stand out from the crowd. It will also go into some of the challenges we’ve had with implementing land cover classification at scale, and how Open Street Maps came to our rescue! And finally, where to next? Why we’re excited to integrate this into Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) reporting, and other future applications.
U3LEYU.title: Environmental Monitoring with Large-Scale Land Cover Classification

3BPEP8.description:
Open Street Maps contains many geospatial datasets that are useful for Disaster Risk Planning, Disaster Risk Reduction and Disaster Management. One such dataset is the Fiji Building outline database. This database potentially holds all building outlines, building construction material and building function. Following TC Winston in 2016 it became apparent that Fiji needed better geospatial data to plan and respond to such natural disasters.

In 2018, the University of the South Pacific Geospatial Science students undertook an assessment of the Fiji Building Outline Database on Open Street Maps. As a result, we were able to determine there were still substantial areas of Fiji with no building outline data.

In August 2019 UNITAR-UNOSAT together with the University of the South Pacific (USP) and the Fiji Government conducted a Mapathon at the USP Lower Campus in Suva from 26th-28th.  Named "Fiji Missing Maps 2019", UNOSAT arranged for an experienced mapathon expert from OSM Asia Pacific Office in Indonesia to facilitate the event. Through this capacity development initiative, the OSM expert also conducted training of trainers for local mapping champions, equipping them to operate future Mapathons.

The Mapathon was promoted via the Missing Maps Website. Participants included Geospatial Science students from USP who acted as lab demonstrators to help members of the public and government officers.  Particularly pleasing was the international response with volunteers from all over the world adding to the OSM Building Outline Database.

This presentation will cover our experiences and the results of Fiji Missing Maps 2019.
3BPEP8.title: Fiji's First Missing Maps Map-a-thon - Fiji Building Outline Database for Disaster Planning and Risk Reduction

AJQQVC.description:
Land Information New Zealand publishes LiDAR data open source through the LINZ Data Service and Open Topography. Promoting resilience to climate change and a better understanding of our nation. 

This involves processing billions of points and pixels. Requiring intense computation and most of all a keen eye on detail. 

This quick talk will give you a glimpse into the three dimensional world of LiDAR. 

I will show how open source tools are so much more than ‘quiet achievers' in our QC workflows.
AJQQVC.title: Point Clouds, Pixels and Open Source Awesomeness – Investigating LiDAR Data

HGNRXX.description: LINZ has a long history of using Open Source software dating back to the first open database systems we published on the web in the mid-'90s.
