As LINZ's role in managing and publishing geospatial information for the wider NZ community has grown, Open Source software and the implementation of open standards have been a powerful enabler to meet our customer's needs. This journey hasn't come without its challenges within the government environment. In this presentation, I will cover LINZ open source journey, why we use Open Source, and how we use it within the department today.
HGNRXX.title: Why LINZ uses Open Source software

H38YK7.description:
If you’ve voted at an election in Australia you’ve most likely eaten a Democracy Sausage (or perhaps a Democracy Cupcake?). They’re a fundraising phenomenon that is as uniquely Australian as Phar Lap or throwing a shrimp on the barbie. For the last 16 State and Federal Elections, a scrappy band of volunteers has been mapping this particularly Australian cultural institution at [democracysausage.org]( https://democracysausage.org).

This talk will discuss how a Twitter in-joke took off and became bigger than Ben Hur. We’ll begin with a short history of the humble Democracy Sausage, what it is, and why it exists. We'll cover some of the delicious challenges we've encountered - from dealing with poor polling place data to scaling from a core team of five to an extended volunteer group of more than twenty.

We’ll also discuss the infrastructure we’ve built to enable us to crowdsource data for thousands of polling booths, before closing with a few of the challenges we’ve yet to solve (maybe you’d like to help out with them?).

This is a beginner-level talk aimed at anyone with an interest in web maps and open data. You should have some knowledge of what it takes to show some dots on a map and a sense of humour.
H38YK7.title: Delicious Democracy: snagging and mapping citizen data

9US7CS.description: This presentation will provide examples of what the present-day geologist/mineral explorer is doing with QGIS. I have been running QGIS workshops for geologists in association with the Australian Institute of Geoscientists since 2016 and I will highlight the QGIS features most valued by geologists. Geologists require the ability to assess multiple data sets and QGIS gives them the ability to do this. Being able to bring satellite imagery directly into your map window has been a major advance in the interpretation of geological data. Plugins allow for remote sensing data to be sourced, processed and presented as required by the user. Other plugins allow drill holes to be plotted in plan and in cross-section. The use of free open source symbols and patterns has extended the capabilities of geologist to produce presentation quality maps. Many geologists work as individual consultants or contractors and the open source world is a fantastic resource of software to allow them to do their work without the constricting licensing conditions or software costs.
9US7CS.title: Geoscience applications of QGIS: a bold new world in mineral exploration

QN8SYY.description:
A city's urban mobility characteristics have a significant impact on the quality of life, economic potential, and safety of citizens.

In Oceania, these characteristics vary wildly. From Port Moresby to Melbourne, we'll look at the different ways citizens move through their cities and the state of roads, public transport, cycling, pedestrian mobility, and accessibility for the mobility impaired.

An exciting development we'll cover is the increased involvement of citizens in shaping the way governments approach mobility. We'll look at how tools like OpenStreetMap, street-level imagery and computer vision are being used by citizens to understand mobility trends and advocate for change.
QN8SYY.title: Urban mobility across Oceania: How citizens are using imagery and OpenStreetMap to influence government policy

KGDBJL.description:
Our world is full of distractions and we as creators of (online) maps add to it.

We create maps that overload our audience with information and hide important details in our maps.

People can only retain a limited amount of information and we should be mindful of that.

Let's be cautious if we need that basemap and if we need all the extra information on the map. Or if we can use colour sparingly and use annotations to help our audience to retain more information.

Let your data shine.

This talk will show the audience how to declutter your maps and create distraction-free maps. It will show plenty of examples of maps that can become distraction-free maps.
KGDBJL.title: Distraction-free (Online) maps

RCP99Q.description:
Koordinates moves data around – a lot of data. But what does it take to build successful products on open source software? In this talk, we’ll discuss the practicalities of supporting a platform that underpins the critical workflows of thousands of data users. For example:
  * WFS was designed for a world where servers were expected to take on the workload of internal clients. How do we scale GeoServer to provide OGC compliant services to a broad and unpredictable audience?
  * GDAL is powerful software, how do we make sure our outputs are correct and how do we manage change as this large and active project moves forward?
  * What new developments in open source can we leverage to provide high availability services?
RCP99Q.title: Building for Reliability with FOSS

MW3RDJ.description:
NIWA manages national databases for NZ climate, hydrometric and water quality data. It is critical that these data are accessible by clients, stakeholders, NIWA staff and relevant managers and decision makers as well as the public. NIWA has developed web services to provide access to summaries of these data, based on the international OGC Sensor Observation Service, served by Open Source software from 52 North. To make these data genuinely accessible to users, NIWA has developed Open Source clients tools that anyone can use to connect to NIWA (and other) SOS services: a QGIS plugin and an R package (SOS4R). NIWA has also provided a demonstration Shiny application, with source on Github package to help those wanting to use this approach to access sensor data.

This presentation discusses NIWA's approach, the tools involved and some of the lessons learned.
MW3RDJ.title: Open source and open standards for sensor data sharing

VTYQNS.description:
Manaaki Whenua – Landcare Research makes extensive use of map caches for its online mapping services such as [Our Environment](https://ourenvironment.scinfo.org.nz/), [S-Map Online](https://smap.landcareresearch.co.nz), and [Antarctic Environments Portal](https://environments.aq). For a single service, the caches comprise ~920M tiles (3.4Tb in size).  

Generating map caches used by MapServer / Mapcache traditionally has been a very compute resource and time expensive exercise.  Our presentation explores vertical and horizontal scaling to reduce the total time of creating caches for our operational services.  Amazon Web Services (AWS) was used to trial the vertical scaling component and New Zealand eScience Infrastructure (NeSI) was used to trial horizontal scaling.  We will provide an analysis of the testing results and discuss the development challenges on each system.
VTYQNS.title: High Performance Map Cache Generation

G8PCZW.description:
Motivated by the numerous stories of drivers being trapped in their vehicles for hours after an accident, we’ve been developing a crash detection service to help motorists immediately after an accident.

The help could be anything from gathering information for an insurance claim; to organising a tow truck & transport home; through to calling an ambulance on their behalf if they’re seriously injured or unresponsive.

Behind this service will be a data & analytics platform built on open source and cloud based infrastructure; which will ingest accelerometer, gyroscope and GPS data at up to 100 times per second, per user. Combining that with open data such as weather, transport and Open Street Map data, we hope to change the way we prevent, understand and respond to vehicle accidents.

After briefly touching on the business case and product design process, this talk will dive into the open source and cloud technology behind the platform, and talk about some of the challenges of starting a product from scratch with limited data science and data engineering resources.
G8PCZW.title: Building a movement data and analytics platform to de-stress customers and save lives

WYPACK.description:
This year Geoscience Australia announced the creation of the ambitious Digital Earth Africa initiative, modelled on the rising success of Digital Earth Australia. The goal of the Digital Earth platforms is to make petabytes of satellite derived data freely available and accessible to inform policy, stimulate economic growth, and build a deeper understanding of our dynamic planet.

The Digital Earth platforms are built on open geospatial data and open source technologies. From the Open Data Cube and the growing library of Python based remote sensing algorithms to TerriaJS, Docker images and Terraform scripts, all our work is shared with the world as reusable, extensible and free.

This talk will delve into how:
* the Open Data Cube works,
* using Xarray and Jupyter Notebooks revolutionised Geoscience Australia’s approach to developing remote sensing applications,
* community movements such as Open Geospatial Consortium standards, Cloud Optimized GeoTIFFs and Spatio Temporal Asset Catalogs drive the open architecture behind the Digital Earth platforms.

Hear the story behind the hype as we explore the past challenges, lessons learned, future opportunities and how you can get involved.
WYPACK.title: The Open Data Cube and working towards a Digital Earth

MZXJ78.description:
Earlier this year, Joseph Elfelt of Mapping Support published an amazing resource: a text file listing over 1800 public US geospatial data sources. Covering federal, state, and city agencies, the file effectively pointed to hundreds of thousands of publicly accessible authoritative geospatial data layers. On the surface, this looked like a massive win for open data advocates.

A closer look, though, leads to a more sobering conclusion. First and foremost, the sources are all public ArcGIS Servers, with some occasional public data portals thrown in. Most of these servers contain poorly titled data intended for internal, not public, usage. It's common for agencies to change URLs, or delete the server without warning. HTTPS isn't uniform. And it’s a server. It's a far cry from open and accessible data.

Where portals are used, they generally haven’t changed or improved in the last six years, despite rapid developments elsewhere in the geospatial industry. Metadata publication in portals is inconsistent. Raster imagery often isn’t supported. Service levels are unreliable. Licensing is absent, contradictory, or "pretty legal".
 
Data publishing is clearly an afterthought for most agencies, and standards are persistently, frustratingly low. Why is this still the case, well over a decade into the open data movement? In this talk, I'll build on the work of the Civil Analytics Network at Harvard University to point out some of the annoyances—major and minor—that are preventing agencies from publishing their open data to a professional standard. And I'll conclude by arguing that advocates need to keep pushing for better, and not just more, open data.
MZXJ78.title: Why is open data publishing (still) broken?

J7STRW.description:
Geographic proximity to the locations of different community resources (e.g. GPs, supermarkets, and schools) affects public health and welfare in both positive and negative ways, for example reducing social isolation or increasing the risk of obesity. Close proximity to community resources provides easier and more direct opportunities to perform daily tasks, such as shop, meet friends, or see a GP. Time and financial costs of access are also reduced, freeing them up for other uses. When linked to socioeconomic status, population density, and urban status, community resource accessibility analysis can support health policy and improve outcomes for individuals living in deprived areas.

Neighbourhoods are the most commonly used unit of scale in community resource accessibility research, often taking the form of existing, outdated census units. But how representative of the people living within them are they? Issues arise when trying to generalise results to different groups of people living nearby each other, such as the Modifiable Area Unit Problem (MAUP) or the "Local Trap".

Road network analysis is used to perform community resource accessibility analysis with the assumption that individuals always use cars as their transport method, but what about people that don’t have access to a car, can’t drive, or prefer other modes of transport? By understanding transport choices of individuals, community resource accessibility can be assessed through a different lens by including pedestrian or public transport routes, or limiting maximum search distance to a reasonable walking distance.

Crowdsourcing neighbourhood data from people living in them can create more representative areas and allow for neighbourhood delineation to be explored based on personal characteristics of individuals. To crowdsource neighbourhood data, open source code and tools were used to create a user-friendly website to crowdsource neighbourhood data from the general public in Wellington.

A range of repositories of open source data were used to collect locations of different types of community resources, such as schools, primary healthcare facilities, and food retailers. Using these, analysis was performed using a range of Python packages (including geopandas and pandana) to compare community defined neighbourhoods to existing spatial units in terms of spatial properties and access to different community resources.

This presentation will cover current progress of this master’s project and our next steps.
J7STRW.title: Where's your hood at? Crowdsourcing Neighbourhoods using Open Source Tools

UZFMN8.description:
Geoscience Australia (GA) is the custodian of a significant collection of national aerial photography, curated by GA and its predecessor agencies. The data extends over 70 years, from the 1920s through to the mid-1990s. This archive represents an important resource for understanding Australia’s changing landscape as the majority of the collection predates high resolution satellite imagery.

Digitisation of this archive is an ongoing priority as some of the original negatives are now very old and starting to degrade, but the approximately 280,000 images digitised so far are currently difficult to discover and access.

Similar but smaller archives of aerial photography are maintained by various state government agencies, and some are quite mature in their adoption of digital discovery and access, however, each agency has implemented their own system, generally locked to a proprietary platform with little capacity for federating data across agencies.

GA has therefore partnered with Data-61 under the Platforms for Open Data (PfOD) program to design and build a canonical metadata repository for images in the collection, and an open API for discovering and eventually accessing these images.  The project has a strong focus on open source and standards-based solutions, with the hope that state government agencies will come on board, facilitating federated discovery of imagery across state and federally managed archives.

The project is a fascinating example of old technology meeting new, dealing with metadata sourced from nearly century-old hand-written documents on the one hand, and the latest cloud deployment technologies and emerging API standards for geospatial data discovery on the other.
UZFMN8.title: Opening a treasure trove: The Historical Aerial Photography project

AYSFPH.description:
Despite Cloud Native technologies and containerisation becoming the *de facto* standard for developing and deploying web applications over the last half-decade, our server-side GIS applications are still often deployed on carefully crafted, long-lived and individually managed virtual machines or physical servers.

Over the last year, we have successfully transitioned our GIS deployments from a traditional service architecture to a fully containerised deployment and integrated tightly with Cloud Native technologies such as Object Storage and Load Balancers. By taking advantage of Kubernetes and its philosophy of rapid development iteration, high availability and scalability, our team can now focus on application development and maintenance, while the platform and servers are fully managed by our cloud vendor. We have managed to decrease ongoing server cost, increase deployment stability and most importantly – greatly increase development velocity.

In this talk, we will share our experience exploring the trials, challenges and benefits we experienced in migrating and running free and open source GIS applications outside of a traditional server infrastructure. We will discuss how to split and containerise previously tightly integrated applications, how to create new microservices to enable these applications to scale, and how to integrate with available cloud technologies.

More specifically, we will explore:

* What is Kubernetes and "Cloud-Native"?
* What Kubernetes does and doesn’t do well
* Challenges of adapting FOSS GIS applications to Cloud-Native technologies.
* How Open Source software helped us in our journey.
* Our experience using a cloud-native approach.
AYSFPH.title: Cloud Native GIS - The value of development velocity in GIS and why you should consider a shift to cloud native

TXTLAL.description:
As a community-driven project, OpenStreetMap (OSM) provides mapping guidelines and a Wiki where the community agrees on certain mapping norms. These norms are, however, only recommendations and there is no mechanism that enforces the contributors to comply with them. Contributors' edits may not follow these mapping guidelines, and local communities often deviate from the best practices. While this provides freedom in the collection of diverse geographical knowledge, it also makes it hard to assure a high-quality dataset of homogeneous quality — and hence usability. This is particularly important with guidelines focusing on the way how objects should be represented and mutually related, rather than what to collect and not to collect. The correction of the edits not following community standards is, in turn, also carried out by the community of contributors, who may have difficulties finding OSM features that need to be corrected. While quality assurance tools (e.g. Keep Right, Osmose) assist with this task, they only capture a subset of the community standards and do so inconsistently.

Here, we explore an approach to using data-mining methods to automatically learn prevalent patterns in the representation of certain classes of spatial objects. The underlying assumption of this data-driven approach is that the majority of objects in the dataset are mapped correctly. From these patterns, we learn rules that enable to identify outliers -- potential errors in OSM data. For example, if the majority of bridges in the dataset are crossing something (likely an obstacle), then this pattern can be adapted as a rule. Thus, if there are some bridges that are not crossing any other objects, they would be seen as potentially erroneous and should be inspected. Expert contributors may then assess these objects, and make corrections if necessary.

Apart from analyzing patterns in well known topological relations between spatial objects such as disjoint, crosses, and meets, we have investigated patterns in ternary spatial relations which are not commonly considered. In particular, the connectedness of a linear object on both sides (e.g. a road bridge should be connected to roads on both sides), and betweenness of spatial objects (e.g. an alleyway should be in between properties). These spatial relations pose interesting problems in terms of how they can be modelled, represented, and reasoned about.

We present the results of our studies using frequent pattern mining on data in Victoria, Australia, and are keen to discuss with the community candidate features that would assist to better identify corrections to the OSM dataset.
TXTLAL.title: Learning rules and detecting errors in OpenStreetMap data: PhD research

FKP9T9.description:
Changes and treatments to New Zealand’s roads occur daily. However, there is no central register to record changes.

A New Zealand agency needed to identify curves in roads that had been classified as a danger and determine if they had been adjusted. A novel approach was needed given the lack of data recorded. 

Orbica was supplied with a dataset (oocc – out of context curves) that showed all curves along all New Zealand roads. We narrowed the dataset to “not acceptable” and “not desirable” curves for state highways and used Open Street Map (OSM) to find out if the roads had been modified or treated (i.e. had changed from a curve to straight). The key difficulty was determining whether the changes in OSM were made for aesthetic reasons (i.e. to tidy features) or because an actual road treatment had taken place. There are thousands of OSM edits, and we needed a way to define them. 

To do this, we used the oocc dataset to extract the segment (or curves) from the 2017 OSM dataset and the 5/2019 OSM dataset. We matched the curves, then calculated attributes to describe the relationship between the old curve and the new curve. We then developed a Deep Neural Network AI model to predict (based on attributes) which were aesthetic changes, and which were due to road changes/treatments. 

The model produced about 30 curves, of which 20 were real road changes. We also assessed changes in speed, so the total number of treated curves (including speed changes) for the period 2017-2019, was 219.

We used PostgreSQL and python to achieve this and mapped the results with GeoServer and Mapbox.

This represents a novel and innovative approach, using opensource technology, to identify road treatments.
FKP9T9.title: Identifying post-treatment roads using Open Street Map, PostGreSQL and Python

7CERXH.description:
New Zealand Transport Agency’s (NZTA) Crash Analysis System (CAS) contains almost 1.5 million crash records with hundreds of attributes that describe when, where and how a crash occurs. Orbica and partner company Catalyst were tasked by NZTA to develop a user-friendly web application to live stream the database so that transport planners and engineers (with no prerequisite knowledge of SQL) could easily build complex stacked spatial and aspatial queries with drag-and-drop, ease of use and intuitive controls.

NZTA, a central government agency, accepted our proposal to design the solution completely using opensource technology.

The following components and corresponding APIs were built for CAS: 
- A React, Leaflet and WebGL based front-end 
- A PostgreSQL/PostGIS and SQL Server spatial-based geospatial database 
- PHP, SilverStripe, web socket-based layer for data streaming

Orbica mixed and tweaked several existing Leaflet plugins to create comprehensive modular components for the GIS aspects of the CAS solution. Main features included:
- A fully “edit geometry” standardised plugin including the following:
  - `Leaflet.FreeDraw` 
  - `Leaflet.draw `
  - Specific business editing functionalities

This works in conjunction with:
- Map data visualisation: crash feature results from queries are displayed as heatmaps, cluster view and PIXI/WebGl specific visualisations capable of handling millions of features (business requirement functionality).
- Schematic/mapping data visualisation: collision diagram. We created a dedicated 2D graphic system based on an opensource web data visualisation framework (PIXI.js WebGl framework).

Relevant features/components will be shared with the open-source community soon.

CAS has been successfully deployed and the road safety community is using it to output complex collision diagrams and reports to help them target and advocate for road safety improvements, as well as store and share queries with other road safety practitioners.

NZTA is now investing in opensource technologies for new projects. This adoption represents a significant growing confidence in the robustness of opensource technologies from the government sector.
7CERXH.title: Crash Analysis System: a crash data analytics and visualisation platform

TXMLJF.description:
Maps often show a simplified view of the world in order to highlight a single issue. Real-life, on the other hand, is messy, contradictory and multifaceted. This means there are always alternative ways to visualise geospatial data, and our choice of which facets to highlight within the data has political implications. Sometimes showing diversity means embracing complexity, and oversimplification leads to an illusion of homogeneity.

In real life, I’m a first-generation immigrant to Australia. Like all immigrants, I’m constantly haunted by anxieties and self-doubts about media portrayal, public perception, cultural identity and issues of belonging. Luckily I do data visualisation for a living, and I believe that facts can be the best therapist. Naturally, I’ve made maps to answer some of my very personal questions, make sense of the world around me, and bring to light data which is obscured by other maps that I see.
In this talk, I’d like to cover:

- Mapping techniques that convey the richness of human data: dot-density maps ([where do people come from](https://smallmultiples.com.au/articles/the-languages-we-speak-in-sydney--melbourne/), [who did they vote for](https://smallmultiples.com.au/projects/australian-election-results-one-dot-for-every-vote/)), and using edible media for maps ([chocolate](https://notasingleorigin.com/))
- A number of mapping projects that provide unique perspectives on multicultural Australia
- Using open access data to answer very personal questions and raise public awareness

The goal of my talk is to encourage people to appreciate the beauty of complexity, and its importance in the field of cartography. Maps can help us see the unpredictability of the individual and the permeability of the group at local and national scales.
TXMLJF.title: Messy maps to make sense of a complex world

7NHAFF.description:
QGIS started back in 2002 as a simple hobby project with only a handful of developers and a small user base. Since then, it has grown into one of the most popular cross-platform open source spatial desktop tools available, with an ever-growing developer and user base, widely used in many sectors, even as a full replacement for commercial offerings.  This growth has not come without cost or growing pains to the project and community. A growing user base and an ongoing effort to be taken as a serious alternative to commercial offerings have led to a shift in developer and user expectations for the project. 

As QGIS has grown into areas and user bases the early developers never dreamed of, some of the feelings the project had have changed, and this might have zapped some of the fun.  Was this inevitable, as we pushed the project with more and more features and promotion in the spatial community?  How do you maintain the same feel for the project, while at the same time becoming more serious?

What about the users and the community?  Have their expectations now changed for the project? At what point did we notice a change in the community and the levels of service we were required to live up to?

Long-term-release, better build process, better documentation, UI translations into many languages; these all make great software, but at a cost for a mostly volunteer-run project. When does the project switch from pure volunteer to a more commercial entity?
7NHAFF.title: The life of open source spatial with QGIS:  From hobby to grown up, with bonus growing pains

TTUMBS.description: The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI) is an archipelago located in the Pacific Ocean that is home to several globally endangered wildlife species.  In order to provide the best management and conservation of these species, CNMI Division of Fish and Wildlife (DFW) biologists regularly collect population data through various field surveys.  In the past, these surveys were conducted using paper field forms that would be manually entered into databases while spatial data was collected using handheld GPS units.  Recently, DFW has moved towards automating data collection and management using free and open source solutions in order to reduce paper buildup, minimise data entry error, and generally streamline operations.  This presentation will outline the workflow and process that the CNMI DFW has implemented for near-seamless integration of field data into spatial and tabular databases.  Rugged field tablets are fitted with custom-built Python applications (using PyQT GUI) that are used to document wildlife surveys while open source GIS software (Intramaps Roam) is used for field navigation and mapping needs. Output are then synchronised to a local server where they are programmatically subset and shuttled to appropriate directories for future analysis and summarisation. Utilising these open source solutions provides a fast and efficient flow of data collection and management with the flexibility of specialised functionality required to survey species within the CNMI.
TTUMBS.title: Using open source software to map and survey wildlife populations in the Northern Mariana Islands

9UUSTQ.description:
In 1835, the HMS Beagle arrived at the Galapagos Islands, igniting a new era of science and history. This voyage was the dawn of island biogeography, the study of the spatial distribution of species and ecosystems across time. This voyage also harboured unintended consequences: a virgin ecosystem on an originally unpopulated archipelago only a few hundred years ago, the Galapagos Islands in 2019 are home to a growing population of 35,000 people and host 275,000 tourists a year.  Just as this area is a hotspot for studying biodiversity and biogeography, there is also a unique chance to map and analyze human and urban geography. 184 years after Charles Darwin, students from the University of Chicago joined a project led by the Mansueto Institute for Urban Innovation to map the urban landscape with Mapillary, using 360-degree cameras. 

Machine learning, computer vision, and geospatial analysis allow imagery to become data about levels of urbanization. While the Galapagos Islands offer one insight, many other islands across the world demonstrate the potential to study their unique patterns of urban development, including the vast array of populated islands in the Pacific region and beyond. What kind of urban challenges can street-level imagery solve in isolated island environments? What kind of data can OpenStreetMap derive from island imagery? What do automated detections in the images tell us about growth and change?

In this presentation, we’ll take a visual journey using Mapillary imagery across many islands of the world: from the Galapagos and Santa Catalina Island to the Faroe and Canary Islands; from Réunion and Zanzibar in the Indian Ocean to Singapore and Tasmania; from Cuba and Guadalupe to Hawaii and Iceland.
9UUSTQ.title: Island Mapping: Measuring Urban Footprints with Mapillary & Open Source Tools

G7DV3Y.description:
Successfully using and maintaining an open source GIS infrastructure requires time and extensive technical capabilities. Tasks such as creating and maintaining virtual machines and servers, understanding, installing and configuring open source applications, building data exchange pipelines, backup processes and security hardening, are daunting and often beyond the everyday realities of working inside smaller institutions and organisations.

At the same time, an open source GIS deployment unlocks an innovation potential usually inaccessible when dealing with licensing fees and a lack of control over proprietary technology. As a globally recognised leader in open source technologies, Catalyst is committed to helping organisations in their transition to open source GIS. We have created a managed GIS platform to simplify FOSS adoption while keeping in full control over your GIS back-end applications.

This talk focusses on how embracing open source technology has given two New Zealand Territorial Authorities the freedom to innovate delivery and improvement of their geospatial data and services. Using examples from production systems across New Zealand we look at how both authorities have created public data portals, dashboards, web mapping applications, and achieved direct integration with external data sources. All while improving reliability and scalability of their underlying GIS systems and data stores. We explore how, by removing the barriers of proprietary licensing, open source fosters local and global collaboration, enables local communities, and allows local government to reinvest licensing cost in research, development and their communities.
G7DV3Y.title: Enabling Local Government Innovation with Open Source Software

Edwin Liava'a.bio:
Edwin has a personal philosophy - "I innovate and provide solutions, not problems".

With over 20 years of experience working in the Pacific Islands region providing contextualized solutions and capacity building in ICT, his passion is driven by harnessing inter-cultural competencies. These competencies go well beyond technical knowledge and leadership qualities, because each Pacific Island has its own unique local context. Also important is the ability to possess a high level of cultural flexibility and tolerance to be neutral when it comes to discussions that might overlap from being politically correct to being in-correct.

Edwin believes that "The best idea should always win and we hire smart people to tell us what to do, not for us to tell them what to do."
Edwin Liava'a.name: Edwin Liava'a
Edwin Liava'a.shortBio: Edwin has over 20 years of experience working in the Pacific Islands region providing contextualized solutions and capacity building in ICT.
Edwin Liava'a.title: CEO

Dr. Kate Crawford.bio:
After successful careers as a pharmacist, a teacher (K-12), an academic, international researcher and software developer, Kate is now the director of a consultancy company Eviva Pty Ltd, an Honorary Principle Research Fellow at the University of Wollongong and an advisor to the Spatial Industry Business Association in Australia. She has experience in cross cultural settings including as a founder of the ANTEP program at Ernabella, South Australia and in Indigenous business development and program development in collaboration with communities.

Major projects include national programs to engage students and their parents in emerging Citizen Science projects, Community programs to connect older people with their community via digital technologies (Living Connect) in Illawarra region, Research with the University of Wollongong and Defence Science and Technology Organisation to enable more independent self-directed collaboration in the field (ARC Discovery Program). After much experience in early IT design and development, networked interactive communication technologies and related social innovation and problem solving, her current interest is the use of spatial technologies as tools in different cultures and to enable more sustainable practices for land and water management.

Miriam is co-founder of projects based in mobile applications and location intelligence technologies and the Geochicas initiative where she promotes more women participation and knowledge sharing in geospatial spaces.

For the past few years Miriam has been highly involved in promoting OpenStreetMap and Humanitarian OpenStreetMap (HOTOSM), increasing the participation of the community in Mexico and LatAm by giving workshops, conferences and coordinating efforts among key players in open data.

Currently she is involved in open data, autonomous vehicles, partnerships and data analysis initiatives.

She is currently a Developer Advocate at Glitch, a platform for building full-stack web applications in the browser. She cares a lot about map projections and probably wants to talk to you about most cool things!

Current areas of professional interest are structured data and reproducibility, but I also dabble in transportation and economics. I also do freelance web development as [spatialparalysis.xyz](https://spatialparalysis.xyz). I have worked as: a paper-boy for the Evening Post (made redundant age 12); a GIS tutor at Victoria University of Wellington (VUW); a Research Assistant for an economic/public policy think-tank; and, for a few years and until recently I was living in Raglan, working for MetOcean Solutions (now a MetService subsidiary) as a GIS & Web Developer. Now I'm a father and husband before all else. I have a Masters degree in GIS from VUW, and after having written all this I realise you can probably just [find me on LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/richardmlaw/). What LinkedIn won't tell you is that I *really* love [a cup of good, hot, black coffee](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XjkVgc6gIqk).

9S7T9U.name: Keith Moss
9S7T9U.bio:
I’m a data geek, occasional software engineer, and a bit of geospatial tragic. I’ve built more web mapping applications than I care to remember - for everything from delivering satellite data in support of bushfires and floods to mapping sausage sizzles and orangutans.

For a living, I work for the Western Australian government where I run the state’s open data team and work to convince public servants of the benefits of making data open, machine-readable, and API-enabled. I’m passionate about applying the user experience principles from our digital world to the broader work of government – building better public services by understanding needs through user research, data-driven insights, and co-design of services.

But most of all, I love helping people to learn, understand, and use data and technology and seeing those “Ah-ha!” moments when they get it.

At Manaaki Whenua (and whenever I've got a free minute), I develop the [LUMASS](https://bitbucket.org/landcareresearch/lumass) spatial modelling and optimisation framework for ecosystem services and soil erosion modelling, geospatial data processing, and the optimisation of spatial resource allocation, such as sediment mitigation measures.

GHSHKM.name: Nyall Dawson
GHSHKM.bio:
Nyall has been a core developer with the QGIS project since 2013. During this time he has contributed over 5000 commits to the project, and today is one of the most active developers on the project. Nyall’s contributions to QGIS cover a wide range of areas – from improvements to the map rendering and symbology engines, enhancements to labeling and print layout functionality, right through to optimisations of the underlying spatial processing algorithms utilised by QGIS.

Nyall is the proprietor and lead developer at North Road Consulting, an Australian based spatial development consultancy which predominantly utilises international co-funding and crowd funding campaigns to finance development into open source GIS applications.

SYCPXT.name: Brent Wood
SYCPXT.bio: I have worked at NIWA (or its predecessors) for over 40 years. I have been an enthusiastic user of open source and supporter of open standards and open data since the 1980's. Starting computing with CPM/80 on 4Mhz Z80 cpu's, I have seen a few changes over the years! I was a founder of the Wellington Amstrad User Group and WellyLUG, ran a public FIDOnet & USEnet BBS before the internet came along, and was an NZOSS council member for several years. I am a Charter Member of OSGEO and the NIWA representative in OGC. I have attended and presented at most FOSS4G conferences in the last 10 years, as well as at the Wellington Postgres Users Group and, more recently, WOSSAT.  in 2016 I won the People's Choice NZOSA for services to Geospatial Open Source in New Zealand. I am passionate about Open Source, Open Data and Open Standards and am fortunate to have an employer who also values these and supports my efforts in this area.

RE3QB8.name: Simon Nitz
RE3QB8.bio:
Simon part owned Digital Mapping Solutions Ltd which was sold in 2016. Simon then went on to set up an geospatial open source business called Pinpoint Geospatial Solutions Ltd (PGS) in 2018. 

Simon is highly regarded throughout New Zealand as a leader in his field and has also undertaken numerous work in Australia. He has provided over 30+ years of GIS consulting and training services to organisations, focusing on both desktop and web mapping systems. His core strengths are as a GIS System Implementer, GIS Application Developer, GIS Database Administrator, and GIS Project Manager. An acknowledged web mapping technology expert amongst his peers, Simon brings a vast knowledge of not only web mapping technology but also web platforms, desktop GIS Systems and GIS services in general.

Simon regularly runs QGIS training, GeoServer training, PostGIS training, SQL Server training, GeoNode training, Python for GeoSpatial training and Intramaps training through his business Pinpoint Geospatial Solutions.

Y7DUVW.name: Violaine Doutreleau
Y7DUVW.bio: I am French and initially a land surveying engineer (2011). I am located in Tahiti, French Polynesia. After a few years of professional experience between Madagascar and France, I discovered OSM in 2014 during a job in a design office doing accessibility surveys (I needed data). Since then I haven't stopped trying to share how powerful this ecosystem is. I initiated the OSM Madagascar community in July 2015 through a training event in the capital as a volunteer for CartONG. I also took part in the Missing Maps project (mapping the most vulnerable places before disaster occurs) with CartONG, as a coordinator. Lately, I have moved abroad and then created *A Vos Cartes* in May 2018. *A Vos Cartes* offers OSM expertise and SIG (GIS) training in Tahiti and environs. With *A Vos Cartes*, I carry out a project called « Cartomobil'ite » about mapping accessibility and I accompany the local national geography institute with OSM.

TAQ8UX.bio:
I have a strong commitment to public service and enjoy solving user-focused challenges through collaboration. My experience draws from a foundation land surveying, geodesy, and measurement science. I have a strong passion for Open Data, Geospatial IT, and the collaboration of open source communities. 

Past roles in LINZ include Geospatial Analyst in the Geodetic team, setup and management of the LINZ Data Service (https://data.linz.govt.nz), and Group Manager of Data Services. Most recently, I have taken the role of Chief Technical Leader providing thought leadership and strategic technical advice from a whole of LINZ perspective to the Location Information Group.
TAQ8UX.shortBio:
I have a strong commitment to public service and enjoy solving user-focused challenges through collaboration. My experience draws from a foundation land surveying, geodesy, and measurement science. I have a strong passion for Open Data, Geospatial IT, and the collaboration of open source communities. 

Past roles in LINZ include Geospatial Analyst in the Geodetic team, setup and management of the LINZ Data Service (https://data.linz.govt.nz), and Group Manager of Data Services. Most recently, I have taken the role of Chief Technical Leader providing thought leadership and strategic technical advice from a whole of LINZ perspective to the Location Information Group.
TAQ8UX.title: Chief Technical Leader

N9QFYU.name: Byron Cochrane
N9QFYU.bio:
Byron has over 25 years experience as a leader in providing interoperability and data linking solutions in a large number of contexts across the globe. A long time proponent, user and contributor of open source geospatial software, his greatest expertise is in Open Data Standards implementation and development - particularly in the geospatial realm.

Byron has served at various levels of government, the military, and private industry, both in New Zealand, Australia and the US. He has often been turned to by organisations wishing to develop, organise and manage their disparate data using standards-based interoperability solutions.

In recent years Byron has contributed to multiple international interoperability efforts including the W3C Spatial Data on the Web, numerous testbed and interoperability experiments for the Open Geographic Consortium and standards development for ISO Technical Committee 211.
​
In his spare time, Byron enjoys exploring the Nelson region, getting to know the local craft beers, keeping abreast of current affairs, and picking on his mandolin when its all becomes a bit too much.

XZZ3HE.name: Ebony-Jean Ta'avili
XZZ3HE.bio: Recruiting in the GIS and ICT field has been a challenge in Samoa because not many of our youngsters, particularly women pursue education in this field. A highlight for SkyEye was welcoming their female GIS Specialists Ebony-Jean Ta’avili and To’oa Faleaupu Brown. Ebony is a graduate from the University of Canterbury with a Bachelor of Science also majoring in Geography and Environmental Science. The 23 year old found passion in GIS and Remote Sensing after learning how much it could help our Pacific Community. Their areas of expertise involve advanced GIS data processing and spatial data analysis among many others. Ebony hails from the villages of Siusega and Vailuutai in Samoa.

DGRFNU.bio: Chris works in the Positioning and Resilience team as a geodetic analyst.  He has been intimately involved in the development and maintenance of the geodetic datum NZGD2000.  Over the past 30 years he has been involved in many areas relating to mapping and coordinate systems such as software for photogrammetric adjustments, raster to vector conversion of contour data for the conversion of maps to a digital database, development of the national survey and title database Landonline.  He also has contributed to the QGIS project, particularly the delimited text renderer, and maintains a number of QGIS plugins (contour plugin, memory layer saver, LandXML import)

I am a public transport planner and data scientist at MRCagney, where I bring together analysis and strategic objectives to tell the story of how strategic projects might affect public spaces and travel options for people. My work involves data analysis, geospatial analysis, economic assessments and business case writing.

I love doing data analysis, number crunching and generally playing with numbers, maths and visualisation tools.
I am motivated by the purpose of creating better places for people.

XBJMHU.name: Dr Kurt Joy
XBJMHU.bio:
Dr Kurt Joy has a PHD in geology from the University of Canterbury. He’s a geological and geospatial innovator skilled in spatial solutions architecture. His strengths include the collection and analysis of 3D point cloud data, spatial geoprocessing techniques, and the use of UAV’s for field data collection.
 
Kurt has led research teams and developed a UAV hyper-spectral mapping platform for a multi-million dollar Government project in Antarctica’s Dry Valley. He has developed a cutting edge technique for quantifying human impacts in sensitive soils using Structure from Motion (SfM). His specialisms extend to computational fluid dynamics and 3D modelling. He has initiated and implemented new geospatial technologies as a lecturer in Geographic Information Systems for the University of Canterbury and mentored post-graduate students with geospatial problem solving.

He has initiated and implemented new geospatial technologies as a lecturer in Geographic Information Systems for the University of Canterbury and mentored post-graduate students with geospatial problem solving.

JUSHQP.bio: Ivan is a geomatics PhD student from the University of Melbourne, where he researches topological relations patterns in map data. With both bachelor and master degrees in land surveying and geoinformatics, he has been learning about all things spatial for a long time, but has built a particular interest in spatial databases. His tools of choice are Linux, Python, PostgreSQL/PostGIS, and QGIS. He enjoys developing QGIS plugins, and playing with Linux servers.

I've been a platform engineer for [Koordinates](https://koordinates.com/) for ages. I'm a Christian, a husband and father of two small people. 

Back when I used to have spare time, I spent most of it snowboarding, drinking craft beer and doing open source programming. I do a bit of brewing now and then.

I like maps, fast servers and Python. I like upgrading stuff and refactoring code. Sometimes I think I'd be a good janitor, or possibly a demolition person.

AS8HFQ.name: Adrian Cochrane
AS8HFQ.bio:
Adrian is passionate about helping people be empowered by computers through custom software development work.  It’s not enough for Adrian to create something that works - he must know why it works!
​
Adrian graduated from Victoria University of Wellington in 2017 with a degree in Computer Science.  His education in computing began long before that, having learned his first programming language at age 10. 
 
Whilst he was studying at Victoria University, Adrian interned at Catalyst IT for an extended time where he worked on the KELP log file analytics/debugging project and Samba Windows-compatible file sharing project.
 
After graduating he successfully completed several contracts including ones for visualizing shared vocabularies with SKOS and a privacy-conscious blogging site.  Additionally he completed a contract for NIWA to harvest WxS endpoints into GeoNetwork.
 
For his hobbies Adrian enjoys illustrating how software can be better through his personal projects, and is always keen for a game of Catan.

He was the Science Lead on a MBIE Endevour Fund programme of research to explore and analyse the environmental pressures on the Ross Sea region of Antarctica. This tool is one of the outputs of the research programme.

CLGR3M.bio: Andrea is a data visualisation specialist, co-founder and one of the directors of Small Multiples, a data visualisation studio based in Sydney, Australia. She is a strong advocate for data transparency and technology which brings this data to life for the people who it is most relevant to. Andrea has been a passionate teacher of data and visual literacy, including doing workshops for Guardian Australia; lecturing and tutoring final year at the University of Sydney and UTS and General Assembly.

EEDBTF.name: David Gavin
EEDBTF.bio:
I have had the pleasure to work at Geoscience Australia for over twelve years, working on geospatial projects using technologies ranging from Oracle and Java to Python and Postgres. In 2016 I had the privilege of leading a small team that drove the adoption of modern approaches to software development within Geoscience Australia, including Agile development, cloud native solutions, continuous delivery and an uncompromising approach to building effective teams through valuing team culture over technical ability.
Since 2017 I have worked with Digital Earth Australia to build technical excellence, empower scientific staff and grow the Open Data Cube.

WHHPSU.name: Em Hain
WHHPSU.bio: This is my second year involved with FOSS4G SoTM Oceania. Last year was a blast and I can't wait for this year in Welllington. I love cartography with a background in art, history and a childhood with my nose in National Geographic maps. The challenge to tell a story through a map is huge but important. Since leaving the Army 14 years ago, I have worked in consultancies and have a dread of cyan, magenta, apple green as well as redrafts. I work for the Snowy Mountain Engineering Corporation in a team of 7. I love turning people onto QGIS and hearing theirs oohs and ahhs over and over again, each time they find the freedom to map.

GPEQE8.name: Caitlin Adams
GPEQE8.bio: Caitlin is a deeply creative thinker with a passion for solving the complex problems humanity faces. Her deep desire to understand the world around her led her to study physics during her Bachelor of Science (Hons) at the University of Queensland. She then kicked it up a notch by trying to understand the universe as a whole during her PhD at Swinburne University of Technology. As a data scientist, she looks for interesting ways to extract insights from the wealth of satellite data available, as well as new ways to support the community to do the same.

Alex is the current Vice President of Wikimedia Australia, the official national chapter of Wikipedia that supports libraries, education and cultural organisations to improve the coverage of Australian content and sources in Wikipedia and related projects.

GJHR9K.name: Chris Morgan
GJHR9K.bio: Agile and DevOps Lead at FrontierSI. I started my career as a Web Application Developer then moved into Application Development and Support. Became interested in project delivery after being involved in difficult projects and thought there must be better ways. Worked in both DevOps and Agile delivery roles across multiple companies and love to teach the practices, principles and learnings from those exciting areas of expertise.

SJUUQ7.name: Nick Rollings
SJUUQ7.bio:
Nick Rollings is Geoscientist who loves Geospatial Technology

His experience includes working in private industry, local government, consulting, and higher education. In the minerals sector, Nick has worked on exploration for gold, base metals, platinum group metals, industrial minerals, extractive minerals and uranium.  In the environmental sector Nick has experience applying geospatial technologies to forests, grasslands, soil erosion, water quality, benthic mapping, water quality, cultural information management, landscape futures, rehabilitation, hazard modeling and site selection.  

Nick’s current research concentrates on multi-scale UAV and satellite remote sensing for vegetation assessment and coastal assessment, and GIS modelling of cyclone track behavior and impact.  

Nick is a Member of the Australian Institute of Geoscientists (MAIG) and  a Senior Member of IEEE

93BRAX.bio: Sharmila works at Geospatial Research Institute as a software developer.She holds a PhD in Information Science (Otago) and a master’s degree in Computer Science. In her career spanning several years in two countries (New Zealand and India), she has undertaken several roles – lab tutor, researcher and software engineer.

3SRT3L.name: Hugh Saalmans
3SRT3L.bio:
Hugh Saalmans is the lead geospatial specialist for the Mobility.AI team at IAG; helping to develop an industry leading data & analytics platform for movement & mobility data.

For over 25 years, Hugh has specialised in desktop mapping through to cloud based geo-analytics, and everything in between. After a brief stint as a hydrographic surveyor, Hugh’s career has included consulting, pre-sales & product management roles at MapInfo (Pitney Bowes), RP Data (CoreLogic), Intergraph and MapData Services. He’s considered an authority on the PSMA’s Geocoded National Address File (G-NAF) and the use of the geospatial information in the insurance industry.

Hugh is an avid supporter of open data, open source and open standards. Not many people know he has a Bachelor of Surveying (honours) from UNSW.

93J83Q.name: Paul Haesler
93J83Q.bio: Paul has been programming computers since his parents bought him a Commodore 64 in the early 1980s.  He has programmed professionally for over 20 years, engaging in his passion for open source whenever possible.  Paul is currently works as a Senior Software Engineer working at CSIRO-Data 61 in the Web-Geospatial team.  These days he is based in Canberra and is an award-winning home-brewer and is currently writing and recording a science fiction rock opera under the pen-name “Spaceman Paul”, which is also his github id.

RU9YHK.name: Grant Boxer
RU9YHK.bio:
Grant Boxer (RPGeo, FAIG, MGSA) is a consultant geologist with over 40 years’ experience in exploration and mining geology. He was employed by CRA Exploration, Argyle Diamonds and Rio Tinto Exploration from 1978 until 1997 undertaking diamond exploration and evaluation activities. Ten years were spent at the Argyle diamond mine carrying out exploration and evaluation programs, feasibility studies and mine development studies for the Argyle and Ellendale diamond deposits and Argyle’s associated alluvial diamond deposits. 
From 1998 until 2008, Grant carried out project reviews, field visits, project management, drilling and sampling program supervision and project generation, primarily for diamonds in Australia, Brazil, China, India and Tanzania. Since 2008, he has been doing GIS data compilation and mineral exploration project generation work for a small exploration company in Perth, as well as a variety of diamond consulting assignments.
Grant has a keen interest in GIS and remote sensing and was a user of MapInfo and Discover since the mid-1990’s. Grant discovered QGIS about 4 years ago and has been running QGIS courses for geologists for the past 3 years in association with the Australian Institute of Geoscientists.

ETJ8VW.name: Adi Vasiti Radinivuna Soko
ETJ8VW.bio:
Vasiti’s industry experience spans ten plus years in the highly technical field of geospatial science and surveying. She has assisted a number of significant projects while working for the Fijian Government including developing a disaster-integrated system for the Commissioner Western’s Office, the Asian Institute of Technology in Thailand, Fiji’s Native Land Trust Board, and the Department of Town and Country Planning.
In addition, during her stint with the Sugar Industry Tribunal as its GIS Manager Vasiti played a vital role in creating the first GIS web portal that not only linked Fiji’s four main sugarcane mills but also published live harvesting data during the crushing season.
Her completed research will contribute to Fiji’s datum update where she focused on the impact of the new datum to local geospatial users and updated the transformation parameters for the country’s maritime boundary which was initially done by GeoScience Australia.
Recognizing the unsung talent that women in the Pacific possess in the GIS industry, she developed an initiative to recognize these. She is currently working on publishing the first Pacific Women in GeoSpatial magazine (online). The magazine will focus on a total of 10 vibrant women in the Pacific who have been shortlisted from the abstract call. The magazine is in its final stages of production and is scheduled to be published by October 2019. Through this initiative, she champions the course of women in this Industry and this is one way of prompting the skills they have within the Pacific region.
